PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Howe proceeding to address a question to the Treasurer-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services, by stating that last Thursday the Minister invited the Leader of the Opposition or anyone else to provide information about the existence of any affidavit which the Leader of the Opposition claimed was held by the Channel 9 television station and which he also claimed named the Deputy Prime Minister as having been involved in a decision relating to the investigation by the former Narcotics Bureau into activities of the Nugan Hand bank. Can the Minister inform the House of the result of this investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Barton for his question. I have received no information from the Leader of the Opposition concerning the allegations he made here last Thursday, despite the fact that on a number of occasions, both inside and outside this place, I have asked him to do so. I might add that I have not received any information from any other member of the House or from any other person in the community. Because the Leader of the Opposition attempted to cast such serious allegations against the Deputy Prime Minister, I initiated investigations over Friday last and the weekend. Those investigations took the form of interviews with departmental officers both within my Department and outside it. I had requested of the Australian Federal Police that police investigations be carried out with people who may be able to provide information on this allegation. Finally, a thorough search of as many files as possible was conducted. That search and those examinations failed to reveal anything of an affidavit or, on the advice that I received, of any ministerial involvement in any decision relating to the former Narcotics Bureau inquiry into the activities of the Nugan Hand bank.

ANSWER.PARA: The result of all this makes it perfectly clear that the Leader of the Opposition has failed to produce any information whatsoever in support of the allegations he made in his attempt to discredit the Deputy Prime Minister. More than that, there is no information available to me of the existence of any affidavit or that any Minister was involved in the decision relating to the status of the inquiry into Nugan Hand. It would appear that the affidavit which the Leader of the Opposition alleged existed was certainly not in the hands of the Channel 9 organisation, as he claimed. I end on this note: Unless the Leader of the Opposition has something to offer today, we can draw only one conclusion- when I say we, I mean honourable members in this House and the people out in the wider community of Australia-that the Leader of the Opposition used the forms of this House to condemn and discredit falsely an honourable member of it. He did that without any information or evidence at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker-
—Does the Leader of the Opposition wish to raise a point of procedure ?

—Yes, Mr Speaker, I want to signal that at an appropriate time after Question Time, I will seek leave to make a statement on this matter. I imagine, in view of the Minister's comments, that I will be given leave. I have some papers which may be interesting.

—I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce: Is it a fact that over 50 per cent of employment in the production of motor vehicle parts occurs in the State of Victoria and that Melbourne, Geelong, Ballarat, Bendigo, Gisborne and Wodonga have heavy concentrations of automotive industry? Is the Minister aware of predictions by the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers that up to 60 per cent of this employment, or about 7,000 workers, could be lost in Victoria as a result of the Government's motor vehicle policy? If so, can the Minister advise the House where these workers can expect to find jobs in view of the Government's acknowledgement that its economic policies have no chance of reversing the resurgent growth in the level of unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lynch The Rt Hon Sir P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main thrust of the new industry package for the automotive industry is to enhance the longer term viability of the particular sector to which the honourable gentleman has referred; that is, the Australian automotive component manufacturing sector, and at the same time to provide directly for that sector's work force. The Government has always accepted, and does now, that this will involve both employment gains and losses within the existing sector. The new package ensures that a more efficient industry, but still substantial in terms of size and employment, will exist at the end of the 1980s. Completely built up imports, as the honourable gentleman is aware, although partially liberalised, will still be subject to restraint. At the same time the base local content requirement for vehicle manufacturers has been maintained at 85 per cent .

ANSWER.PARA: The only way to achieve the Government's objectives in what I believe to be the best interests of the industry-that certainly includes the component industry-is to encourage further progress towards a more specialised export oriented industry. As part of this process some companies making very high cost parts solely for the domestic market will be faced with difficult but necessary commercial decisions if they are to meet the challenge of intensified international competition. The companies making lower cost components-this includes a number of Victorian companies in the areas the honourable gentleman has mentioned-will clearly stand to benefit directly through exporting world car components to overseas vehicle producers and indirectly by supplying plan producers' components for products which are destined for export. Some companies which are now high cost producers will be able to take advantage of export sales to improve their overall competitiveness and viability.

As for the impact on particular States or regions, it is not for the Government to anticipate the commercial decisions which will be taken within the post-1984 policy framework. We have never denied that there will be gainers and losers but the honourable gentleman surely ought to be the first to admit that this industry needs to be placed on a more competitive basis, able to move increasingly into an international framework, and that the thrust of what the Government has done will certainly be of assistance in the component industry in developing a more viable area of the automotive industry generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment tell this House whether an environmental impact statement is being prepared in relation to the extension and development of Perth Airport?

—I can advise the honourable member that I have directed the preparation and submission to me of an environmental impact statement. The Commonwealth Department of Transport is the action department and will be preparing that EIS. The EIS will be released to the public and comments will be sought upon it from all interested parties so that they can have their views taken into consideration in the preparation of the final EIS.

—I refer the Treasurer to his speech yesterday in which he expressed strong support for further increases in sales taxes. If the Treasurer considers that the sales tax structure is and can be progressive, why in the last Budget did he lift the sales tax rate on the top range of luxury goods by only 9 per cent but double the sales tax rate on what he described as 'lesser luxuries, like household furniture and floor coverings, refrigerators, crockery and cutlery'?

—I would like to correct the honourable member for La Trobe. I did not in my speech yesterday advocate, as he implies, increases in existing sales taxes. What I did was to cast very serious doubt on the veracity of the reasons advanced by another place for rejecting the Government's Budget measures. I also took the opportunity of pointing out the utter inconsistency in the Australian Labor Party's avowed opposition to all forms of tax avoidance and tax evasion on the one hand, and its unremitting opposition to any extension of the indirect tax base, which is the only really lethal weapon against the cash economy, on the other hand.

—Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware that over the last year or two large numbers of young Filipino women have migrated to Australia to marry eligible middle aged Australian men and that most of these marriages were arranged by professional Filipino marriage agencies? Does the Minister agree that many of these marriages have been highly successful but that in some cases prospective husbands outlayed up to $2,000 more than two years ago but have yet even to meet their future wives other than through letters and photographs? Is the Minister satisfied that the marriage agencies involved are acting in a bona fide way and not extracting money by false pretences? What efforts are being made by his Department properly to inform the parties involved of their rights and of the delays which may occur before the arrangements can be consummated? Finally, does the Minister have any other advice to offer these husbands in waiting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that the honourable member and several other honourable members have been concerned about this issue. As a general observation, history is replete with examples of that sort of frustration and very rarely, to my knowledge, is government intervention able to help. In fact, the honourable member gave me warning of his concern and several other honourable members have raised other aspects of this issue with me. Both the Government of the Philippines and this Government are doing their best to analyse the situation, but I have no reason to doubt, on the information given to me so far, that the activities of the majority of these marriage agencies are bona fide. A number of them do provide counselling services in addition to arranging introductions. I should also say that most are Australian-based rather than Philippines-based. Any extensive and expensive delays, such as have been referred to, as a result of the activities of these agencies are certainly to be regretted. Sometimes unavoidable delays occur as a result of normal migration processing or Philippines Government requirements. I can do no more than say that perhaps the husbands in waiting should be patient.

ANSWER.PARA: I recall that in the debate in this House on the Estimates last year the honourable member for McPherson raised the matter with me. I referred to another aspect of the problem in an answer which I gave then-I believe my comment is still valid-when I said that sometimes a cooling off period is not bad in terms of the ardour of some Australians who have taken four weeks annual leave and found that they could comply with the marriage banns and so forth while they were on holidays. There are several aspects of the problem. As far as my Department's resources allow, counselling of prospective marriage partners, both sponsors in Australia and applicants in the Philippines, is undertaken to ensure that the people concerned really understand each other's cultures and what is involved in the marriage. I must say that there is some evidence that misunderstandings have occurred but, other than giving counselling before marriage and after settlement in Australia, there is very little that the Government can, or perhaps should, do to intervene in the matter. Within our laws there is nothing to impede or prevent a marriage because of a short courtship. Sometimes these long distance relationships do involve complications of the kind referred to. I am sure that the honourable member is not suggesting that we can refuse entry to anyone wishing to come here for the purpose of marriage to an Australian resident. Following a number of discussions that I have had with honourable members, we are conducting a study of the success of marriages of the kind referred to. At this stage we have no reason to think they are any less successful than is the average Australian marriage. To the contrary , the early results indicate that probably, in terms of breakdown of marriages officially recorded, their record is rather better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Treasurer been drawn to advertisements in this morning's Melbourne Press which promote a six-month building society deposit at an interest rate of 16.25 per cent? Is it a fact that such an interest rate is about one per cent above the building society lending rate in Victoria? Is it also a fact that this apparently imprudent interest rate policy has been forced upon the building societies as a result of the severe credit squeeze taking grip in Australia, which has driven short term interest rates to a current level of 21 per cent? Will the Treasurer abandon his deliberate policy of attracting capital inflow with high interest rates and instead immediately release some of the $2.8 billion in the bank funds that are locked away in statutory reserve deposits, in order to ease the crisis that is facing many financial institutions ?

—There is no crisis facing many financial institutions, and it is a misreading of the situation at present to imply that. So far as the conduct of monetary policy over the next few months is concerned, as I indicated in answer to a question last week, the Government and the authorities, and in particular the Reserve Bank of Australia, will need to perform a significant balancing act. A number of instruments are available, including the release of some statutory reserve deposits. This may be required at appropriate times and in appropriate measure. I can only assure the honourable gentleman that the situation is being monitored daily, very regularly and very intensely, not only by me but also by the Reserve Bank and by my advisers.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of allegations that public plant breeding will cease if Australia introduces plant variety rights legislation? Will farmers and home gardeners be prevented from continuing to grow traditional varieties or be prevented from retaining seed from those varieties for their future use? Are any of these allegations true? What assurance can the Minister give from the Commonwealth Government on these two issues, and what is the experience in other countries?

—There is no truth in the allegations. Public plant breeding will not be affected in any way by the introduction of plant variety rights. Public plant breeding has long been a highly popular and well regarded program in Australia. A number of institutes in Australia have been involved in it, for example the Waite Institute in South Australia. The fact is that they are not affected by plant variety rights. If they retain their funding they will continue in the same way.
—If they retain their funding.

—If they retain their funding by State governments or raise their own funds in the way they do now they will continue in exactly the same way. Plant variety rights will have no effect on them at all. As to the second part of the question in respect of home gardeners or farmers being able to continue with seeds and plants presently available, again plant variety rights cannot in any way affect the supply of seeds or plants. Plant variety rights can be introduced only for a newly bred plant if, firstly, the breeder seeks to have it accepted under the legislation and, secondly, the plant is accepted by the Australian Agricultural Council. Therefore, plant variety rights cannot in any way affect the availability of seeds and plants presently in the community. The only way they can disappear is if people no longer want to grow them. I think that is a different matter entirely.

—I direct a question to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Government 's humiliating defeat at the weekend in the Lowe by-election. Does the Prime Minister see any lessons for his Government in this defeat? Does he see any lessons for himself and for his leadership? For instance, will he now stop making promises to the Australian people which he cannot keep?
—Order! The honourable gentleman will ask for information and not suggest the answer in the question.

—Will he now honour all the promises he made in the last seven years and then broke? Finally, will the Government immediately change its strategy of economic failure which has created the highest tax burden and the highest interest rates in our history?
—This Government is a government for the long term and not for one by-election. The Government's policies will not be altered as a result of a by-election.

—Is the Minister for Transport aware of the practice followed by both major airlines of cancelling scheduled services to Canberra at short notice ? In view of the disruption and cost to the travelling public that this practice creates, can the Minister tell me what action he proposes to ensure that it is discontinued?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the restructuring of air fares as a consequence of the adoption of the Holcroft report on domestic air fares, there was a substantial rise in air fares between Canberra and Sydney and between Sydney and Melbourne. Undoubtedly this has resulted in a much lower level of passenger use on those airline services servicing Canberra. I have had a number of complaints from members of this House and also from the public about unscheduled or unexpected cancellations of air services to Canberra last year. In October of last year I asked the airlines to adjust their schedules more in line with the passenger flow so that they would not be placed in the position of having to cancel services at short notice, so inconveniencing the travelling public. I had an assurance that they would endeavour to do that.

ANSWER.PARA: Earlier this year there were further cancellations. I have since written to both airlines asking them once again to review their services to Canberra to ensure that they do have scheduled services here that are more in keeping with the numbers of people travelling to and from Canberra. They have now rearranged their scheduling to take that passenger load into account. I have also asked my Department to monitor the situation very carefully. If honourable members receive complaints about cancellations of services between Sydney and Canberra or between Melbourne and Canberra, I will be very pleased to have them. I will make sure that they are sent to the appropriate people who are monitoring the situation and I will take whatever measures are necessary to ensure that people are not inconvenienced unnecessarily as a result of the cancellation of services .

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a report of Amnesty International of continued suppression of democratic and human rights in Turkey, including Press censorship, detention without charge and widespread torture? Can he confirm that, since the military junta took control in Turkey in September 1980, over 60 political prisoners have died and several thousand have been crippled through torture, while over 100,000 remain in gaol, of whom 3,000 face likely death sentences from a military court without the right to legal defence? Is it a fact that the Council of Europe recently censured the military junta in Turkey and urged individual nations to bring human rights charges against that junta? What action has the Australian Government taken with the Turkish authorities in international forums to press for the restoration of democratic and human rights in Turkey? Will the Australian Government actively support the call of the Council of Europe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot confirm the actual figures that the honourable gentleman has quoted but I am aware that, since the imposition of military rule in Turkey, there have been widespread violations of human rights. I am also aware that, prior to the military takeover in Turkey, there was an extremely serious terrorist situation with, according to my information, approximately 20 deaths a day occurring. I understand that there has been some improvement in that respect but there is no getting away from the fact that it has been at the very considerable expense of human rights in that country. The Australian Government has made known its views. Our views are strongly against the sorts of actions referred to in the Amnesty International report and in a report of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. We will be following the discussions of the topic by that body with great interest.

ANSWER.PARA: The obvious final solution can come only with a return to civilian rule in Turkey. I understand that arrangements are now in train for elections to be held in 1983. But so long as military rule continues, or indeed so long as violations of human rights continue, under whatever leadership, the Australian Government will continue to make its views known, as it always has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to the legislation to be introduced into Parliament concerning the regulation of the import and export of wildlife and wildlife products. I ask: Will the Government, when introducing the legislation and in the light of the concern expressed by many Australians about the Canadian seal hunt, consider banning the importation of seal products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time the Government has expressed its concern to the Canadian authorities and has sought information about the practices regarding the seal hunt. The Government has announced its intention to introduce legislation to protect the export and import of wildlife so that it can, more effectively than at present, comply with the obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species agreement and protect the trade in endangered species. It is proposed that the legislation will contain provisions to enable restriction and prohibition of the export and import of flora and fauna that may not be on the endangered list but about which there is justifiable concern. Certainly when that legislation has been introduced and becomes law consideration will be given to the use of the legislative powers to prohibit the importation of seal products.

ANSWER.PARA: The responsibility for the decisions are matters for the Canadian Government. We have ascertained that the seals in question are not endangered. We are continuing to seek further information to ensure that that is the case and that the level of the seal hunt is not raised so high that it endangers the seal. We are deeply concerned about the way in which the hunt is conducted and have brought the concern of the Australian people to the attention of the Canadian Government. So far as we are aware at present there is no importation of seal products into Australia, but the matter is being kept under close study.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Treasurer been drawn to a Social Welfare Policy Secretariat paper entitled: 'Alternative strategies to meet the income needs of the aged'? It makes the point that no figures are available for revenue foregone on tax concessions for superannuation schemes, but suggests figures of between $1m and $2m-a rather wide range. Now that the Lowe by-election is over, will the Treasurer move some Treasury staff from costing the health policy of the Australian Labor Party to the costing of actual Government policies so as to assist us and the community at large to have more intelligent discussions on policies to meet the income needs of the aged?

—I assure the honourable gentleman that costing the enormous additional taxation burden of the Labor Party's health policy does not involve too many Treasury officials. In fact, those sorts of calculations can be made fairly easily. The honourable gentleman asks a very important question about the extent of revenue forgone in respect of different concessions. Some of the figures are not easy to calculate. My attention has been drawn to the study by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat. If the honourable member for Prospect were to examine the Budget documentation of the past few years he would notice that there has been a significant increase in the volume of information provided covering the area generally classified as taxation expenditure. The provision of that information is designed to provide a more accurate measure of the overall cost to the Budget of the provision of certain taxation concessions.
—Not all of them.

—Not all of them, that is right. The honourable member for Gellibrand is quite correct; not all of them can be easily measured. I assure the honourable gentleman that I will examine this question further. If there are ways and means in which further information as to the real cost of taxation concessions can be provided I will see that it is.
—Has the Treasurer recently made any announcements or comments regarding the Government's approach to the taxing of capital gains? Does the Government have any new proposals in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to both questions is no. Appearing in this morning's Press was a rather incomplete report of some comments I made yesterday at the National Congress of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia. In answer to a question I indicated that opinions on different forms of taxation varied very widely in the community and that there were people who supported the Government' s side who had some different views on taxation from those of the Government. What the report did not record, in which respect it was very deficient, was a very precise statement of the Government's position on capital gains and wealth taxes which I made to the Congress. Amongst other things I said:

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it plain that some of the things Mr Kelleher-
He was one of the other contributors-

has recommended, particularly in the capital taxes area, are plainly against the present policy of the Government. The present Government is opposed to capital gains and wealth taxes and I shouldn't leave this congress in any doubt about that particular point. I know there are different views on this in the community but I don't want there to be any misunderstanding about that particular point of view.

That was a very plain, unambiguous, succinct statement of the Government's position. So I say to the honourable member for Bradfield that there is absolutely no ambiguity about our position on capital gains and wealth taxes. We do not have any vague positions which involve tightening up, whatever that may mean, the provisions of 26AAA, whatever that may mean, as are entertained by honourable members on the other side of the House. We have a completely unambiguous opposition to capital gains and wealth taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show that, of the increase in the total inflow of foreign investment in Australia, over one-third was investment simply in buying the shares of Australian companies. Is the Treasurer aware that, according to the Foreign Investment Review Board, 293 Australian companies were taken over in the last financial year, and in a further 398 companies loss of Australian ownership was involved? Accordingly, can the Treasurer inform the House when he will prevent this alarming takeover of Australian industries and resources by foreign investors, discourage speculative investments and seriously do something about providing jobs for the half a million unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite plain from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's question that he believes it is possible to operate a selective stop-start approach to foreign investment. The plain truth is that unless this country is prepared to have an assured flow of foreign investment and unless we are to provide a set of guidelines which provide long term encouragement and security to foreign investment we will have to settle for a lower standard of living. The Australian Labor Party imagines that we can have the benefits of foreign investment without having the debits of foreign investment. That sort of dream world may be attractive in theory but in practice it simply does not work.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the last four or five years this Government has very patiently built up international investor confidence in Australia. That has involved providing a set of foreign investment guidelines which maximise the benefits of foreign investment in Australia but, at the same time, ensure that this Government is second to none in its determination to protect a fair share of the development of the resources of this country for Australian equity. I can assure the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that I have had more criticism directed at this Government's foreign investment policy from those who want it to be more liberal than from those who want it to be more restrictive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Right Honourable Humphrey Atkins, M.P., Lord Privy Seal in the Government of the United Kingdom. On behalf of the House I extend to our distinguished visitor a very warm welcome.

—I refer the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to Press statements announcing substantial reductions in the operating profit of the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd and in particular BHP's calculation of the negative effect that its iron and steel operations have on that profit. Is the Minister aware of the announcement that BHP has reached agreement to grant its iron and steel workers a 38-hour week? Considering that the Minister's portfolio charges him with representing the consumer as well as business, can the Minister advise the House whether he has any intention of increasing protection by either quota or tariff, which would allow BHP to pass the costs of this unilateral decision on to the Australian public?

—I am not aware of any circumstance under which BHP has been promised any concessions in this matter. It is a matter purely for the Minister for Industrial Relations and not for the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs.

—My question of the Treasurer follows his unambiguous answer to the question on a capital gains tax by the honourable member for Bradfield. Does the Treasurer recall in that answer declaring quite categorically that there was on the part of the Government complete and unambiguous opposition to capital gains taxes and wealth taxes in all their forms? Does this mean that we can anticipate very soon the repeal of sections 26A and 26AAA of the taxation legislation, which sections the Government has administered for the past seven years and which impose capital gains taxes?

—The question of the effect in taxation terms and in terms of our taxation system of the operation of that section, which in its present form was, I think, the result of an amendment introduced by the former member for Melbourne Ports when he was the Australian Labor Party Treasurer in 1974, is a matter of debate. I do not accept the notion that that can be categorised as being in the nature of a capital gains tax. I inform the Leader of the Opposition that there is no current intention to repeal it.
—Can the Minister for Administrative Services provide further details on the disposal of Commonwealth property arising from decisions taken in the review of Commonwealth functions?

—I can confirm that one of the RCF decisions was that the Government would start to examine properties that it owns in order to dispose of them. That examination is now under way. It encompasses a wide range of Commonwealth-owned properties-everything from-
—What about the Parramatta land? Will you sell that?

—We will get around to that too, very soon. The properties that we are examining whether to get rid of range from Department of Defence owned land, such as rifle ranges, right through to unwanted office blocks and so on. Included in our examination are about 19,000 properties of one sort or another. The honourable member will readily recognise that to examine each one of those to see whether its functional use is still economic, whether it can be replaced by something more economic, and so on, is a very time-consuming task. However, our estimate is that in the next three years we will be able to dispose of property by sale in the normal manner to realise about $70m. The first property, one in Hobart, has been declared for sale already. I hope that we will now be gaining some acceleration in this process and will be able to declare further properties very quickly.

—I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction whether he recalls his statement last week in this House in which he called on the States to exempt first home buyers from stamp duty. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that first home buyers in the Australian Capital Territory, which comes under the powers of this Government, are required to pay stamp duty? Will the Minister set a good example by taking action to exempt first home buyers in the Australian Capital Territory from stamp duty, or is his call to the States just another example of double-talk by the Government?

—It is true that stamp duty is applicable to house transfers in the Australian Capital Territory. It is worth remarking that on a house mortgage transfer of about $40,000 the amount involved in the Australian Capital Territory is $768. Under the Government of New South Wales the amount is about $980. So there is a significant concession as far as home owners in the Australian Capital Territory are concerned. I would have thought that as a man representing the Australian Capital Territory the honourable member would be aware that the matter he raised does not come under my portfolio-it is under the excellent administration of my colleague the Minister for the Capital Territory. That Minister shares with me the important task of having served on the joint Commonwealth-State Ministerial Council on Housing Costs. As Chairman of that body I know that at the appropriate time the Minister will be making representations to ease the burden of stamp duties in the Australian Capital Territory. The States may also be seeking to ease the burden. It is to be hoped that they do not follow the example of New South Wales which took from poor people $241m, or twice as much as it spent on welfare housing last year.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the problems now being experienced by the Tasmanian apple industry? Why did the Minister refuse an additional export licence for Tasmania? Is the Minister aware that the rating of the Premier of Tasmania is about 11 per cent at the moment because--
—The honourable member will cease giving information. He may ask his question.

—If the apple industry in Tasmania cannot be cleaned up and if harmony cannot be reached in respect of some of the problems in the industry, will the Minister give an assurance that he will intervene in an endeavour to right an industry that is of so much importance not only to Tasmania but also to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of some of the information that the honourable member has given to the House. I was unaware that the rating of the Premier of Tasmania is only 11 per cent. That certainly spells disaster for the Australian Labor Party in Tasmania. The sooner an election takes place in Tasmania the better. As to the main thrust of the honourable member's question, I can only say that there were applications for extra export licences from Tasmania for the selling of apples. That would answer all the accusations of interference. The officer concerned would not be talking about telephone interference; he would be talking about something which would be recorded on the file. That indicates the seriousness of the accusation at the present time. Such an accusation cannot be refuted by a mere denial made in this House. It can only be refuted by its being proven that no representations were made by one Minister to another, by its being shown that there is no evidence in the file of that having occurred.

Let us make it very clear: Even in matters related to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation the Opposition is entitled to access to information. The easiest way for the Parliament to be satisfied that no representations were made in this case is for us to have access to the relevant file. It is as simple as that. All the Leader of the Opposition asked was that the Prime Minister deny that such representations were made, but the Leader of the Opposition was gagged when asking that that be done.

Surely one of the Ministers concerned, particularly the Minister in charge of the matter at the time, should have had the initiative, when he heard of the broadcast, to come into this House some hours later and say that there was no truth in the accusation. That would have been a very simple thing to do. Because that was not done we now have, by way of this motion, a suggestion that something horrendous is being done for the first time. That is utter nonsense. I ask honourable members to recall what happened to the Australian Labor Party in the past when accusations were made against it about secret commissions, money and everything else. People were put in their graves as a result of that. Conspiracy charges were laid against them. All sorts of issues were involved. Money was paid to Sankey and nobody was able to produce any evidence about who paid it. The rotteness of that conduct might give reason to say: 'You want to do something about the Standing Orders'. What is proposed now would inhibit the freedom of a member of Parliament. All that we are asking is that the accusations of the officer be thoroughly investigated and that the Parliament be shown evidence to the effect that what the Ministers are saying is true. That is the simple issue.

—There is more than enough evidence on the basis of what has been presented by Volkman from these documents, by his statements in private, which I have repeated here, all of which may well be wrong, but which ought to be tested . A representative of Channel 9 told me of that fact and claimed that there was an affidavit in existence. The point is that the allegations have been made. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, last Thursday- -
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. On what basis is the Minister speaking?
—I am waiting for him to indicate that to me.
—Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement.
—Is leave granted? There being no dissentient voice, leave is granted .

—Last Thursday the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) came into this House and made serious allegations concerning the Nugan Hand Bank group and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). Today he has done the same thing. On the first occasion he said that he had an affidavit to back up his statement. Today his evidence is based on the statement of a man named Volkman and documents which he has refused to table in this House.
—They are on your files, aren't they?

—That is the difference. I will come to that in a moment, too. That is the only difference between what was said last Thursday and what has been said today. The only similarity between last Thursday and today is that on both occasions the Leader of the Opposition has made a total fool of himself. First of all, let us go back to Thursday and see how the matters unravelled as we heard the accusations made. Much has been made of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition would not have dared to come into this place to make such substantial accusations against the Deputy Prime Minister except that he was needled into it, that somehow he was forced to do it by the provocative actions of the Government and its members. Let us get the facts straight. The Leader of the Opposition came into this House and moved a motion. He did not follow the usual courtesies. Nobody was advised with substantial time that he was going to move that motion nor about what he was going to do. Obviously, he deliberately failed to do that because his plan was to come in here, move that motion and, immediately after, name the Deputy Prime Minister as the person involved. That is hardly the action of a decent man who was demanding justice and a revelation of the proper facts of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The next thing that happened was that he said that he would not have dared mention the Deputy Prime Minister again, except it was the needling of the Minister for Administrative Services-that is me-that got him going. I looked back on the record and I note that I interjected four times. The poor old Leader of the Opposition, the man who pretends to be Prime Minister of this country, was provoked into naming the Deputy Prime Minister again because I interjected four times. On Thursday, the Leader of the Opposition maintained that he justly named the Deputy Prime Minister because of an affidavit which he had. Today we learn that he had to base that statement that he had an affidavit on something somebody from the media told him and he has named Channel 9. He will not tell us who the person was from Channel 9 who told him that Volkman had identified Mr Anthony. I do not know about whom he is talking. But I can talk about Channel 9 and some of its representatives. As a result of the accusations made by the Leader of the Opposition I requested the Australian Federal Police to go to Channel 9 and find out, as much as they could, the truth of the matter. The first thing that they were told by a representative of Channel 9 was that no affidavit existed. I have here a report which was made on 16 March by Detective Sergeant Moody of the eastern division of the AFP. He had telephoned one Mr Patrick Lindsay of Channel 9. The record of interview that he has provided me with states:
Lindsay says he knows nothing of an affidavit, only what was said by the Leader of the Opposition in the House.
Secondly, he states:
He knew that the Leader of the Opposition had named Mr Anthony but has no knowledge of where he, Hayden, got it from.
He continues, in my view quite rightly:
Lindsay said that he is a fool if he could not support these accusations.

I accused the Leader of the Opposition of telling untruths in this place last Thursday. I used a stronger word. But he is indicted out of his own mouth again today when he claims that somebody at Channel 9, somebody whom he will not name, told him that the affidavit existed. I again ask the Leader of the Opposition whether he wants to clear his good name. He is the one who is always talking about mendacity in this House. I have here a record of an interview from the man responsible for the interview on Channel 9 and he says that he had nothing to do with an affidavit and he thinks that Hayden is a fool if he could not support the allegations. Well, so much for the affidavit.

After the affidavit question came up I went to some trouble to try to establish just what was the truth of the matter, not so much as to come in here and be able to score substantial points on the Leader of the Opposition but to make sure that the allegations were properly investigated and that if anybody was involved appropriate action would be taken against them. That was the main aim of having the inquiries made. So that the House will know what the form of those inquiries were, let me outline them. I asked the Australian Federal Police to make inquiries. The police carried out investigations with an inquiry to Channel 9, with an inquiry to Mr Patrick Lindsay to whom I have referred, an inquiry to Mr Liebmann who interviewed Mr Volkman on television, and inquiries to persons who were named by the Leader of the Opposition, which I will come to in a moment , Mr Brian Bates and further Mr Harvey Bates, which I think will also be of interest to the House.

Now we come to today's allegations, fresh allegations. But what do we have? Once again we have the Leader of the Opposition telling us that Mr Volkman somewhere, sometime, to someone-none of which we know-had named the Deputy Prime Minister. Again I ask the Leader of the Opposition: Where did Mr Volkman say this? When did he say it? To whom did he say it? Then we will be able to test whether the Leader of the Opposition has been telling lies today or not. I have a record of interview with Mr Volkman. In looking through the record of interview that the police have provided me with, it is clear that Mr Volkman makes it clear to the interviewing police that he cannot remember ever naming the Deputy Prime Minister when he went on that television interview. I cannot ever remember seeing a record of interview which shows that the Deputy Prime Minister was named. So we have to ask the Leader of the Opposition whether he really believes that anybody listening to this debate can believe him on this matter. It simply just does not add up. You have to do much better than that it you are going to make the sorts of accusations you have now made twice in this House if anybody is going to believe you.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will address his remarks through the Chair instead of directly across the chamber.

—The Leader of the Opposition also referred to a letter which he says shows-and I will use his words; I think I am doing so accurately-that this investigation by the Narcotics Bureau stopped dead when the letter went forward. It is quite clear that what Mr Bates was directing there was that there should be no overt inquiry but that it should remain a covert inquiry. That picks up the quite interesting point in the debate that began here last Thursday because I think this is about the fourth time we have caught out the Leader of the Opposition in telling untruths. Here is another one. When he came in--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister continues to use the word 'untruth'.
—Well, misleading. I withdraw it. It is the fourth time that he has misled the House.
—The honourable gentleman is not entitled to use that term either.

—That is the correct form.

—The Leader of the Opposition has already made a fool of the honourable member. He should not get into the act as well. In March 1978 I said that that letter had been sent. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Today we had the Deputy Prime Minister move a motion about members of parliament being slandered under privilege. —The Leader of the Opposition asks for a judicial inquiry. We have had the Narcotics Bureau--

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to inform the House of decisions on refugee policy and procedures which have been taken by the Government following a review of our refugee and special humanitarian programs. The review was initiated following my overseas visit in June-July 1981, which involved extensive discussions with government leaders and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on the composition of the refugee and displaced persons population presently around the world. This was the first comprehensive review of Australia's policies on refugee resettlement since the establishment of Australia's current machinery in May 1977. The review closely examined the nature of the outflows, the motivations of those involved and the continuing appropriateness of Australia's response.

SPEECH.PARA: The guiding principles of the review were those embodied in the Government's stated refugee policy of May 1977, in particular that:
Australia fully recognises its humanitarian commitment and responsibility to admit refugees for resettlement;
The decision to accept refugees must always remain with the Australian Government;
Special assistance will often need to be provided for the resettlement of refugees in Australia;

It may not be in the interests of some refugees to settle in Australia. Their interests may be better served by resettlement elsewhere. The Australian Government makes an annual contribution to the UNHCR, which is the main body associated with such resettlement.

The purpose of the review was to ensure that Australia's response to refugee situations was appropriate to the needs of the people caught up in those situations. Another important consideration was the need to reassure the Australian community that people being brought to Australia for resettlement as refugees under generous arrangements are indeed refugees. During my visit last year I reached the conclusion, commonly held by many involved in both the Indo- Chinese and Eastern European refugee situations, that a proportion of people now leaving their homelands were doing so to seek a better way of life rather than to escape from some form of persecution. In other words their motivation is the same as over one million others who apply annually to migrate to Australia. To accept them as refugees would in effect condone queue-jumping as migrants.

In all of this, the Government's primary concern is to maintain the humanitarian focus and integrity of Australia's obligations accepted by our commitment to the United Nations Convention on Refugees. In other words, in order to be humane to those most in need we must apply the definition of refugee carefully and arrange priorities accordingly. In that way we are also fair to others who seek to migrate in the appropriate manner.

The grant of refugee status and the special and generous entitlements that flow from it are means of ensuring that people exposed to or who risk persecution may be offered sanctuary and protection. This is a proper and humanitarian response from a nation such as Australia where the values of human dignity and compassion are strongly held. Our record in providing assistance to refugees is an admirable one and all Australians have reason to be proud of that record. The 400,000 refugees who have resettled in Australia since World War II and the $96m which has been contributed since 1978 to provide assistance to refugees around the world are adequate testimony.

Humanitarian though this has been one should acknowledge gratefully that as a nation we have benefited enormously from the acceptance of refugees. They have broadened our attitudes and greatly enriched our way of life. They have achieved an excellent reputation in varied fields of employment. They are playing a significant role in helping to break down prejudices and to make us more receptive to new cultures and new ideas. As a consequence I believe we are now a less parochial people. Moreover, as individuals, they commit themselves totally to this country for, unlike migrants, they know there is no going back to their old home.

The manner in which refugee problems are solved is a complex and difficult process. Importantly, it involves a balance between compassion and realism. The provision of a durable solution, to use the language of international instruments dealing with refugees, involves judgments about the best solution for the situation of the people involved. It does not follow that resettlement in other countries is always the best or the most appropriate solution. For most refugees, the most desirable solution is for an individual to be free to return to his home in safety and with hope. Only when this is not possible does the question of resettlement in other countries arise. It follows that an important task for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is the development of arrangements to repatriate refugees where this is possible. In recent years the High Commissioner has been responsible for a number of successful repatriations in Africa and Asia. At the present there is some prospect of further repatriation arrangements being developed to allow some Indo-Chinese in camps in South East Asia to return to their countries of origin under appropriate conditions.

In a world beset by political turmoil and upheaval, the number of people who have been uprooted from their countries and have become displaced is growing daily. The High Commissioner for Refugees estimates the number of displaced persons as being approximately 10 million. A high proportion of these people are not, however, refugees within the accepted definition of that term set out under the United Nations Convention. That definition is as follows:

A person who owing to a well founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country.

The phrases 'is outside the country of his nationality' and 'well founded fear of persecution' constitute the key elements of the definition. As may be readily appreciated there are difficulties in defining absolutely the conditions and circumstances which bring about a situation in which a person may be validly judged as being within the terms of the definition. However common sense and humanity usually point to the salient factors. Thus a threat to life or freedom on account of race, religion, nationality, political opinions or membership of a particular social group is categorically persecution.

Many, perhaps most, people who become caught up in a mass movement can make only slight claims to having suffered persecution. Many people who voluntarily leave their country to take up residence elsewhere are motivated by a variety of different factors-economic reasons, the desire for change, family considerations or other reasons of a personal nature. In some cases the reasons for leaving may also include a dislike or abhorrence of the political systems or ideology operating in their homeland. In some cases people may face some form of discrimination in their daily lives. Motivations to leave are often complex but, unless these motivating factors are accompanied by a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality or membership of a particular social group, or political opinion, refugee status should not apply.

We have a solemn humanitarian obligation to ensure that our limited program places are reserved for the genuine refugees. We must exclude those people whose claims for refugee status are suspect. This is a most difficult task. But it is one that must be carried out if we are to fulfil our undertakings under the United Nations Convention, maintain the Australian community's support for the Government's policies and ensure that persons who should be subject to review under immigration policy are not able to circumvent those policies by being accorded refugee status incorrectly.

Against this background, the Government has decided, after consultation with other governments, both those of first asylum countries and of resettlement countries, major community groups within Australia and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, that Australia will:

Tighten refugee selection criteria and procedures for all programs with the particular objective of excluding from refugee entry those persons who do not meet the criteria allowed for in the United Nations Convention;
under this revised procedure refugee determination will be made according to the application of these criteria on an individual basis;
despite these changes, persons who cannot meet the refugee criteria may be eligible for entry under special humanitarian programs or migration criteria.

These arrangements will be brought into effect as soon as possible. Selection assessments will be made by Australian officials who will be operating under criteria which is quite consistent with the United Nations Convention definition . These new procedures will replace the former practice of relying on mandate status accorded by UNHCR. While in no way derogating from the helpful role played by UNHCR in assisting us with determinations in the past it is entirely appropriate that Australia should now employ its own procedures. The decision to do this brings our practice into line with arrangements provided for under the Convention itself. This arrangement will ensure that determinations of status are made responsibly and with compassion. As in the past, our refugee officials will continue to work closely with the High Commissioner for Refugees whose role will continue to be an integral and important element in the development of the Government's refugee policy.

In this latter context, I would like to say that the Government and indeed the world community is particularly indebted to the office of the High Commissioner for its efforts on behalf of refugees. Honourable members will recall that the office of the High Commissioner was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for 1981. I would like to take this opportunity to say that the Government will continue its strong support for the High Commissioner's efforts in providing humanitarian assistance to all refugees.

The decision taken by the Government on individual determinations has not been taken in isolation. As I have said elsewhere, the decision was arrived at only after careful consideration of the approach being taken by other governments and UNHCR and, where appropriate, after extensive consultation. Countries of first asylum are continuing to accept a heavy share of the refugee burden. There are many countries in this situation around the world but I have in mind here particularly the countries of South East Asia and Austria which are generously providing temporary refuge for a large number of asylum seekers and, in doing so , continue to demonstrate a humanitarian willingness to provide assistance to those who seek it, pending the development of durable solutions for those people .

Where persons have been classified as refugees, Australia will continue to give priority consideration to those refugees with family in Australia. This again is also in accordance with international practice. The Government has decided to terminate two minor programs-those for White Russians and Christian minority groups in the Middle East. The claims of those of the White Russian group and Middle East Christians will, in future, be assessed against other criteria.

The program for White Russians commenced post-World War II and has accomplished its objective. The program-under which 12,000 people have come to Australia-will wind down with effect from 30 June 1982. This date has been decided upon in order to ensure that any persons who still wish to be considered have adequate time to come forward. Any future claims by such persons will be considered against normal criteria for migration. The program for Christian minorities from the Middle East ceased as a refugee program with effect from 31 December 1981. Persons in this group are eligible for consideration under the provisions of the special humanitarian program along with other Middle East minority groups experiencing similar difficulties, discrimination and hardship. Persons within those groups are assessed on a case by case basis and, on the basis of their present general circumstances, they are more likely to be accepted under the special humanitarian program than as refugees. The record of some individuals may, however, justify their being accorded refugee status, and the appropriate priority and assisted passage, which is not available to persons coming under the special humanitarian program.

The Government has also decided to increase the program for refugee resettlement from South America. There is a growing number of South American nationals who are in need of resettlement. Accordingly, we have, in consultation with the UNHCR, enlarged both numerically and geographically our South American program to cater for persons from South America who can satisfy criteria for refugee status and resettlement in Australia. The situation of refugees in this area and their needs and wishes with regard to resettlement are still being assessed by Australia and the international agencies. At present the numbers seeking resettlement in Australia are quite small. This is because of geographically inspired traditional attitudes-most think automatically of resettlement in North America or Western Europe. Generations of displaced persons from South America have settled in North America and Western Europe. It is natural that the overwhelming majority now displaced will seek to go there also, especially as they often have relatives there. Gradually, however, more will come to Australia and join the small but successfully settled band of South Americans already here.

The Government has also decided that it will no longer announce individual program ceilings for particular refugee groups. This will enable us to have maximum flexibility in responding to different or changing situations without creating undue expectations. The outcome of those decisions will be obvious at the end of each financial year. In line with these moves we have also been looking at other ways of dealing with the problems of displaced people other than those who are refugees. I expect, for example, that the recently announced special humanitarian program will provide new alternatives to refugee resettlement, particularly for those in difficult circumstances or with family ties in Australia who cannot satisfy refugee criteria. Displaced persons who do not qualify for refugee status are now being interviewed in various parts of the world and I would expect the next financial year's intake figures to reflect substantial benefits to individuals and to Australia as a result of this program .

Another matter of concern for South East Asia and Australia has been the continuing outflow of persons from Vietnam. I have had a series of discussions with my counterparts in Malaysia and Thailand about ways in which it might be possible to deter the outflow of persons making extremely hazardous journeys in small boats from Vietnam. The plight of people on those voyages has often been frightful and has aroused pity, horror and anger simultaneously in the hearts of those of us who have seen the results of those experiences. For this reason, we have been negotiating with Vietnam for an orderly departure program from Vietnam to Australia. Without such an arrangement, desperate people will always find a way around the moratorium on illegal departures imposed by Vietnam.

In all of my dealings with Australians of Vietnamese origin I have stressed the fact that negotiations on an orderly departure program from Vietnam of their relatives might not be possible for some time. I am, however, delighted to announce to the House today that following a negotiating visit by officers of my department to Hanoi last week, an arrangement has been reached in principle with the Vietnamese Government. The arrangement, which comes after some years of negotiations, is based on globally applied migration procedures. The emphasis of the program will be on the reunification of families parted in the tragic circumstances of the last seven years. It is hoped that movement to Australia will begin after procedural arrangements have been finalised over the next couple of months. The successful conclusion of this arrangement is a pleasing and positive development and, I consider, reflects a willingness on the part of the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam to resolve a difficult humanitarian problem in a spirit of goodwill and co-operation. In talking of co- operation, perhaps I could observe at this point how important to Australia has been the new aspect of our relationship with South East Asian countries as a result of the refugee program.

The decisions I have announced today will be of significant benefit to genuine refugees who wish to resettle in Australia. It will mean that Australian resettlement opportunities will be available only to those most in need and whose claims are legitimate. Those not satisfying refugee or special humanitarian criteria must compete for migration to Australia with one million other migrant seekers annually. I am particularly pleased to recognise the role of the Parliament itself in a parallel study of these questions and to note that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in its report on the Indo-Chinese problem commends our management of the problem to date in both its domestic and international aspects and shares my view of the changing nature of the outflow and the need to adjust our approach. In identifying myself with the Committee's report I wish to extend my personal thanks and congratulations to the officers of my Department for the splendid job they have done under extremely difficult circumstances. Australia has reason to be indebted to them and proud of them.

As a result of the present review, I can renew assurances to people in Australia that our generous humanitarian response is directed only to those in genuine need. This is particularly important to people who are seeking to bring their families to Australia under normal migration criteria. These measures do not represent any diminution of Australia's commitment as a major refugee resettlement country. On the contrary, we are extending that humanitarian commitment. The present overall program for refugee and special humanitarian entry is now 24,500, the highest intake ever in this category. My recent announcements of an increased intake of Polish refugees in this current year illustrate that Australia stands ready to respond to new and sudden refugee situations.

Australia's response to the Polish crisis is well known but should be restated briefly here. In conjunction with the UNHCR, Austria and all major resettlement countries, we have processed applications of Poles outside Poland in accordance with their wishes. The majority have not sought resettlement but have preferred to extend their temporary legal status wherever they now are until the situation in Poland becomes clearer and they can seek reunification with their families either in or outside Poland. No Pole outside Poland has been induced to seek resettlement by the actions of other governments and very few have sought to leave those European countries nearest to Poland. The reaction of all interested governments has been most humane and responsible.

This approach has also been advocated by Australians of Polish origin and close consultation is being maintained between them and my Department. As a result, the global figure for refugee and special humanitarian programs announced in the 1981-82 Budget has been increased by a further 2,000 persons to help relieve the congestion in Austria and Germany amongst Poles who are determined not to return to Poland. Special procedures have also been introduced to cope with the unexpected volume of migration applications as distinct from refugees. Of the order of 4,400 Polish refugees and over 1,400 Polish migrants are expected to arrive in Australia this financial year and, in addition to that, there will be approximately another 1,600 East European refugees. This intake is expected to be numerically higher on a per capita basis than that of any other country. We are not, however, endeavouring to outbid other countries but are working with them to meet the best interests of the displaced persons and their families. This situation is under continual review and we will continue to make the appropriate response in terms of changes within Poland and the interests and wishes of the individuals.

I might add that while our global approach to these humanitarian programs gives us great flexibility there is no prospect of our extending other programs at the expense of our principal regional obligations regarding Indo-Chinese refugees. The decision to tighten criteria while increasing our intake is a realistic and fair response to a changing situation and is not a reflection on the integrity of those members of the Australian community who came to Australia as refugees.

I have been dealing primarily with the processing of refugees overseas. The same definition and criteria are used for persons claiming refugee status in Australia and in the application of that policy within Australia similar considerations apply to those I have mentioned. Thus, it should not be easier or harder to be accepted in Australia as a refugee than it is outside Australia and persons who arrive illegally or on visitor's visas ought not to be able to stay permanently in Australia unless they are refugees or otherwise produce the most compelling compassionate reasons. That indeed is the law of Australia agreed upon unanimously by the present Parliament. Just as persons cannot circumvent Australian immigration law and policy outside Australia, they cannot do so inside Australia. People without refugee status or the special humanitarian criteria announced by me in this House on 18 November last cannot gain preference over other applicants for migration. Similarly, persons who come to Australia either illegally or as a temporary entrant cannot stay in preference to others in a similar situation simply because they do not wish to return home. If they were able to do this we would have no control at all over our immigration policy. Indeed, with over a million visitors coming to Australia each year we would have no policy if every tourist, stowaway or deserter were allowed to stay on some pretext, thereby circumventing migration interviews, health checks and security clearances.

Random settlement by persons not going through immigration procedures overseas could cause enormous dislocation to our labour market and to our internal stability and security. The whole point of our immigration policy is to meet Australia's requirements. For this reason the Government established a Determination of Refugee Status Committee to examine all claims in Australia for refugee status. That Committee contains senior officials from all relevant departments and has an observer from the UNHCR. It is swamped with applications, mostly from persons who have only very slim claims to refugee status. That Committee makes recommendations to me and such is its professionalism that I can recall rejecting its advice on only rare occasions.

All of that will seem logical and fair to almost all Australians and would generally not require a statement at such length. I do so simply because a vocal minority of Australians of East European origin refuse to accept the appropriateness of that policy. Such persons desire us to accept anyone who arrives in Australia from a Soviet bloc country in Europe regardless of whether that person had any record of political or other activity which might have brought him or her within the definition of refugee referred to earlier. That simply has never been the policy of this or any other Australian Government so far as I have been able to ascertain. Some cases might have given that impression, especially before we had so many applications and the formal machinery for ensuring consistency. But we do now have that machinery and when the confidential records of cases are compared, consistency is achieved. Because cases must be treated confidentially by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee-the DORS Committee-neither it nor the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs feels really free to comment on cases lest the interests of individuals be harmed. This is often so even when other people make aspects of the case public.

An example of that situation is the recent highly publicised case of the Romanian soccer player, Mr Gheorge Viscreanu, who sought but was not accorded refugee status. His application, as with every other claimant, was examined and determined in full accord with principles and procedures as set out by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Honourable members will recall that the Determination of Refugee Status Committee concluded unanimously that on the basis of the information obtained from the detailed interview with Mr Viscreanu he had no well-founded fear of persecution. A representative of the UNHCR as an observer of that Committee participated fully in its deliberations. It was on this basis that refugee status was refused. Neither in his ill-advised media comments not in his interviews did Mr Viscreanu ever say anything critical of his Government, country or his life at home. On the contrary, he acknowledged that he and his family were well treated. Consequently, when assurances were received by the Australian Government from the Romanian Government that Mr Viscreanu would not suffer any reprisals following his return home there was no reasonable ground for his staying. We need to bear in mind that literally hundreds of thousands of other people who visit Australia on visas similar to that of Mr Viscreanu are refused the right to change of status when their reasons for wanting to stay are never less than his and sometimes-because of family connections here-are greater.

Thus it will be clear that for Mr Viscreanu to have been allowed to stay thousands of others would have had an injustice done to them. The fact is that he was induced to stay by someone more intent on publicly embarrassing the Romanian Government than on considering Mr Viscreanu's wellbeing. Others in the soccer team who received similar approaches declined to leave the team. I have no doubt that once the glamorous aspects of Australian life lost their novelty and he realised that at the age of 20 he would never see his family again he would have undergone the same change of heart as Miss Gasinskaya about whom I have spoken in the Parliament before. People who induce others to seek to stay in Australia and who try to get media attention in the process often lose sight of the interests of the individuals and disrupt their lives for many years to come. In the case of Mr Viscreanu certain media interests paid Mr Viscreanu's Australian sponsor for exclusive story rights. Exclusive stories from secret hiding places might have provided sensational scoops but were not relevant to the functioning of the DORS Committee or my consideration of its recommendation. Nor was the publicity of any benefit to Mr Viscreanu.

Our policy is a most humane one and it is administered most fairly. We can only deal with refugee applications individually and we cannot accept people merely because they come from totalitarian countries. To do so when they are not refugees and have no other special compassionate reasons would only prejudice persons from democratic countries whose claims to remain in Australia are as strong or stronger. Our immigration policy is non-discriminatory on the grounds of race; our refugee policy is likewise. The refugee criteria are universally applied in order to ensure that the concept of refugee status is not diluted to the ultimate detriment of genuine refugees. I present the following paper:
Refugee Policy-Government Decisions-Ministerial Statement, 16 March 1982.

That the House take note of the paper.
