SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee). I am sure that Tolstoy would have been impressed by its length. Obviously there are some very good writers in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I do not know that it required 23 pages to tell us what is inherent in the statement. Nonetheless, it is an important statement and one which we have been promised for some time.
—Will you speak for 28 minutes?

—I will not use 28 minutes because I do not think it is necessary for me to do so. However, I will send the honourable member a copy of what I say in case he is not in the chamber. There can be no confusion as to where we on this side of the House stand in regard to the taking of refugees into Australia. We consider the policy in this area to be of enormous importance. Personally, I think perhaps what Australia has done in the last six years on the question of refugees has been far more influential in our region than any initiative we may have taken in any other policy area of foreign affairs or defence. It seems to me that our neighbours have a much different view of Australia as a result of what Australia has done in a most humanitarian way over the past six years specifically in regard to the Indo-Chinese refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I say too much about the Minister's statement, let me put it in the context of what we are up against when we start talking about refugees. The most talked of figure of the number of refugees in the world is about 10 million. This is contained in the annual report of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and I think that the Minister also mentions it. My inquiries from the United Nations tell me that it regards somewhere between 10 million and 16 million as the number and that 14 million is regarded as a quite conservative figure of the number of refugees in the world. The figure is broken up in the following way: There are 6.3 million refugees in Africa; 3.1 million in Asia, which includes 1.4 million from Afghanistan; 200,000 in Latin America and 3.5 million in the Middle East. I am informed that the count is made on the basis of their having been registered as refugees with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

When one considers those figures it seems that what Australia is doing perhaps pales into insignificance alongside the total number of people in the world who are displaced. This raises the point that Australia and all the other countries, such as the United States of America, Canada and France, which are taking steps to try to see that some refugees are given a new home, can never possibly entertain the idea that we can continue with this plan in the hope that we can overcome the massive problem. More people are being displaced each day than we can take into our own countries. Political settlement must always receive the priority of what we are doing in this area. We think it is of enormous importance that the Government does more in the political arena about the refugee question. Some problems may look as if they cannot be solved but it seems to me rather ironic and sad that the Government, which said so much about Afghanistan during the Olympic Games, has gone silent on the matter when 1.4 million Afghans have been pushed out of their country by the invading armies of the Soviet Union. The only way we will be able to solve that question is to put sufficient pressure on the Soviet Union to get out of Afghanistan so those people can go back to where they want to go. Those people do not want to come to Australia and the United States. They want to return to the place they call their home-that is, Afghanistan.

That is one question on which the Government has gone silent. Obviously it has gone silent because our trade with the Soviet Union has quadrupled in the last four years. Everything that we sell to the Soviet Union, such as wool, wheat and primary products, has become a far more important political weapon than talking about people who have lost their homes. It is estimated that something like 20 per cent of the population of Afghanistan has been either killed or displaced since the invasion by the Soviet Union. This Parliament is almost virtually silent on the subject.

The other area about which we ought to be saying more-I thank the Minister for including it in his remarks-is the question of Latin America. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has said, on one occasion that I know of in the Parliament, that he felt that perhaps President Reagan had adopted the right path in relation to El Salvador. We are pushing people out of El Salvador as we tried to push people out of Nicaragua. Again there is no way that we can solve the problem of the numbers of people who will be displaced in Latin America. We ought to be adopting a far more constructive attitude in trying to bring about a political settlement in those areas in the way in which France and Mexico initiated the moves to bring about a political settlement in El Salvador so that we are not faced with the problem of making up our minds about how many people we can take from these areas. This situation applies in many parts of the world. Australia is a small country. I suspect that when we travel overseas we realise how insignificant we are in world events and how insignificant our influence is on these matters. However, our voice ought to be continually raised. Taking 20, 000 or 25,000 refugees-as magnificent as that may be on the local scene in Australia-is only a token effort towards the total settlement of having up to 16 million people settled back in their respective countries. On those matters it seems to me the Government ought to be more vocal.

The other question to which I wish to refer also concerns refugees-how many there are and what percentage they comprise of our total migrant intake. I think that we have been enormously fortunate in the way in which refugees have been settled in Australia. Since World War II something like 400,000 refugees have been settled successfully in Australia. We can break this into different periods of history. The more relevant question now concerns the number we are taking at the moment, or have taken during the last three or four years, and from where they came. The Minister's statement makes it pretty obvious in terms of Indo- China, now that we have, thankfully, made a proper arrangement with the Government of Vietnam, that people coming out of Vietnam in the future will go through the normal channels of migration. They will not be classified as refugees. I will refer to that in a moment because I know that a number of members of the Vietnamese community in Australia will not be terribly happy with that interpretation. They think that many of their people who are being persecuted within Vietnam should be classified as refugees because of the way in which they are being treated.

Since I have held the post of Opposition shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I have pushed for more parliamentary activity on this matter in an effort to overview what we are doing. According to the figures given to us by the Minister our refugee intake will be-leaving aside the movements between New Zealand and Australia-somewhere in the vicinity of 25 per cent of our total migrant intake. As that figure has grown, it means that there are fewer opportunities for would-be migrants from other areas to make application and be successful in reaching our shores. Such decisions can cause some friction. I have raised this matter because it seems to me-we are not sure what the immediate future holds, but there is a great deal of concern in the community- that perhaps if the Western world is on the brink of another short term recession that the labour force will suffer as a result. This raises the question about our capacity to settle successfully the numbers of people which we are now entertaining.

I do not protest on behalf of my side of the House about the numbers because we have spoken about the matter on a number of occasions. We have said publicly, both inside and outside of the Parliament, that we find no great cause for alarm . Of course, the unemployment figures which were published last week showed a very steep decline in employment opportunities in Australia. Obviously people will be concerned about what the future holds. If the trend for the rest of 1982 and 1983 follows a similar path to that indicated in the unemployment figures of last week, surely there will be a lot more discussion in Australia about the number of people who come here and the great difficulty that refugees suffer. My remarks are not confined to any particular group. Even if any migrants do have professions they usually have to work in a semi-skilled or unskilled area. They are concentrated in that area of employment which is suffering the worst consequences at the moment in Australia. We have to keep our eye on the situation. I will cite some figures to the Parliament in a moment regarding what is happening to refugees as far as the labour force is concerned. The Opposition is very much a part of the sentiment that will continue to allow Australia to be one of the countries taking refugees. We have done some work on the question of what other countries are doing. This is not a decision that Australia can take in isolation, nor is it a position into which we should be conned by other countries.

The rhetoric on refugees can become rather acute at times. One hears people overseas saying what they intend to do in encouraging people to leave their home countries. A similar situation now exists in Poland. When the Poles reach Austria the Austrians ask around the Western democracies where they should send all these Poles. There is a certain reluctance on behalf of those people with the loud voices, who told the Poles to leave Poland in the first place, to see them settled. Austria has been left with an enormous burden of trying to settle these people in its community. As the Minister said in his statement, in some cases it suits a lot of Polish people, especially those who have been separated from their families, to stay as close as possible to Poland. That is because they have hopes of reunification with their families when things settle down in Poland, or perhaps they think that it may be easier to get their families out if they stay in Austria. Nonetheless, there has been a reluctance, it seems, on the part of the United States of America particularly, to follow through its sabre rattling with a better attitude towards settling the Polish refugees. I am told that the United States of America has pledged to take 9,000 of them in 1982. Numerically, compared with us, that is a pretty poor performance. I know that the Americans put up a Congressman called Derwinski-one would not have to be Einstein to guess his background-and he said that it would go from 9,000 to 100, 000 this year. However, in talking to people who are part of the congressional committee on immigration and refugees-a committee which I have told the Minister we ought also to have here-there is no doubt that there are strong views against any large escalation of the intake by the United States of refugees from anywhere in the world, so it is unlikely that Ed Derwinski will get his way.

Canada is pledged to take 6,000 refugees from Eastern Europe, but there is a mix up there because of the sponsorship scheme which Canada has, apart from its official scheme. It may be that there will have to be more international negotiations about the sort of things that ought to be done in regard to acceptance of refugees, so that each country is carrying its fair burden. We should not say to the Australian people: 'You will carry more than your fair share'. Perhaps a case could be made out that we should carry more than our fair share of the people who come from our region. But Poland is hardly in our region . The Polish people who have left their country, through whatever circumstances, and are left in want in Austria should be treated fairly by all the people in that country or whatever country it may be.

Just to give some idea of the figures, 963,000 Indo-Chinese refugees were resettled up until 1980-44,000 in Australia, 435,000 in the United Stated, 252, 000 back in China, 70,000 in France, and 70,000 in Canada. Of course, those figures will change as a result of the debates taking place in each of those countries. Between June 1976 and June 1981 72,972 persons came to Australia under refugee status-50,040 from Indo-China, 9,296 from part of Eastern Europe, 3,926 Jewish people from the Soviet Union, 7,470 people from Lebanon, 666 White Russians from China, and 1,574 others. That also, I think, gives some idea of the emphasis that we want placed on the Latin America area, to which the Minister referred in his statement, because the people from that area come into the category 'others'. Obviously this is an area which has been ignored. Traditionally they have looked to Western Europe and the United States. Judging from the attitude of the United States in sending back people who are reaching there from El Salvador-some of them, I would think, to almost certain death-we shall have to have a far more humane attitude to those people who are trying to get out as a result of the conflict in that country. We should never lose sight of the fact that the only way in which we shall solve that problem in the long term is with a political settlement.

I want also to refer further to the Minister's remarks. He talks about passing off many of the groups of people to the special humanitarian program. It may be that it will be a very difficult task for any government to treat the special humanitarian program on the basis of individuals, because there are many groups of people in the world who are among minorities in their own countries and who are being persecuted by a majority government. They do not see the persecution in individual stands. They see the persecution of the community. I refer to what the Minister said last year in his statement of 18 November, as reported at page 3068 of Hansard:

This program has been developed within the broad philosophy of the Government's refugee policy. It will enable Australia to provide a humanitarian response, outside formal refugee programs, in instances of substantial discrimination or human rights violations against oppressed minorities anywhere in the world by governments irrespective of their political persuasion.
He went on to say:

Oppressive regimes and governments whose policies have little regard for basic human rights inevitably cause an outflow across national borders of members of minority groups at risk. We are becoming inreasingly aware of the plight of such people, whose numbers are increasing also. Often, these displaced persons are unable to satisfy the internationally accepted criteria of defining refugees.

I understood from the Minister that perhaps at sometime in the not too distant future he will be following up that statement by telling us how he sees the special humanitarian program operating. Reading from his statement today, there will be a fair overlap of application by people who consider themselves eligible under the special humanatarian program and people who may have previously seen themselves as part of the total group of refugees applying to come here.

I remind the House that last year, on 20 October, a document, which may have been sent to all of us, from the Vietnamese community in Australia outlined the problems that it saw with the changing attitudes that were occurring in Australia as a result of the debate about who was a refugee, because we were sticking strickly, as the Minister said in his statement today, to the United Nations definition-that one had to be outside one's country, that one could not go back, that one was afraid of persecution. We recognised that and classified the person in question as a refugee. But the Vietnamese community wrote to us and said: 'If you are going to do that, you will be ignoring the plight of many of the people in our country who still want to get out of Vietnam and who are still being persecuted for a number of reasons'. This document states:

Since the first groups of people who left during the last few days of the Saigon regime up until now, there have been about 630,000 refugees coming out of Vietnam. Yet we must remember there were 1,200,000 soldiers in the Republic's Army, over 200,000 police and between 600,000 and 800,000 pubic servants before April 1975. That is we have not counted the few hundred thousand people who worked for the Americans and the allies, in various capacities. Now, if we take into consideration their families, including wives, children and others, we are in for some 10 million people. Comparing this figure with the number of people who have already left, we see the fallacy of the argument.
That is, the argument of people who say that those who want to leave Vietnam have already left. Then the document poses the question:

If there are so many people, how can any country help all? From our first hand experiences, we know the desire to runaway from tyranny is always there, but that is not going to be the decisive factor. The overriding factor is whether the people have the ability to do what they wish to do. As of now, that important factor is diminished every day. The good boats are gone. It is increasingly difficult to find boats in the country. It is getting more and more difficult to find the fuel (State owned and even the State is short of it). The equipment for sea going such as compasses and sea charts are no longer available . In addition the Government's patrols are getting tougher and tougher and more and more efficient. People may say you can buy off the officials. That is partly true but you can buy only one locality, not all of them along the way. Therefore the chance of being arrested is always big. It is also known that the longer people stay in the country, the less able they can afford the price to buy off the officials.

So it goes on. There were persecutions in Vietnam as a result of people not wanting to serve in the army in Kampuchea. There was persecution because the person happened to have been a professional person. There was persecution because the person had faith which was not in favour with the regime. In spite of the arrangement which we on this side of the House would welcome whereby the Vietnamese Government will allow orderly departure, perhaps many of these things can be fixed up. But if it is to be on the basis of family reunion, which is now one of the major criteria for the operation of the immigration laws as they will apply from 19 April, there are many people in Vietnam who consider themselves being persecuted, who will not have a member of their family outside Vietnam and who, according to our laws, we are now cutting off. I do not know that there is terribly much we can do about it, but we have to take that into consideration.

Before I conclude, I want to refer to the problems of the refugees once they have arrived in Australia. I realise that the Minister's statement dealt only with the question of intake and the interpretation of 'refugee', but I do not think it is possible for the Parliament to discuss the matter without looking broadly at what may happen to these people when they arrive in Australia. That, indeed, is the essence of how successful we will be in the future. If they are not settled satisfactorily, our refugee program is going to drift with the tide and end up on the rocks. In spite of how humane we may feel, if the majority or a very large proportion of the people we bring here cannot find employment or cannot keep their families and if there is friction between the local community and the new arrivals, obviously a lot of people in the community will be very upset and angry and they will question the wisdom of continuing with this campaign.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, in comparison to other immigrant categories, a very high proportion of refugees enter the labour force. About 44 per cent of all migrants who arrived in 1980-81 entered the labour force compared with 54 per cent of refugees. As I said earlier, an extremely high proportion of refugees is semi-skilled or unskilled. In 1980-81, 92 per cent of refugees were in this group compared with 51 per cent of migrants. The refugees appear to have a higher unemployment rate than any other migrant group. The figures show that about 20 per cent of recent refugee arrivals were unemployed at the end of 1981. This figure compares with 10 per cent unemployment for general eligibility migrants, or a national average, as it was then, of 6.3 per cent. One need go no further to establish that refugees have a far more difficult task in settling into this country than other migrants. It may be that the post-settlement services which we have are not adequate or it may be that we are looking at figures that are produced at a time when the overall economic recession in this country is making it increasingly unfavourable to people in this category-semi-skilled and unskilled-to come into the country.

As I said at the outset, I think our refugee program is of enormous importance to any cultural differences which may be in our makeup. I think it is enormously important on how people see us because it has meant, particularly in the last six years-I pay credit where it is due-that we have safely buried, for all time, the white Australia policy. There may be groups of people or individuals in Australia who are not totally happy with that, but nonetheless that is what the last six years has done; it has been an enormously important step for Australia. Inasmuch as we have taken that attitude primarily to the people who were displaced in Indo-China, we must now balance the books and see that people who are unsettled in other areas are looked at in the same even-handed way that we went about the problems in Indo-China. We must sit down with other countries which are taking refugees to see that we are all sharing the responsibility of the numbers of these peoples that can be settled.

In the 'State of the Nation' speech delivered by the Prime Minister last Tuesday we were told that, by 1985, Western Europe and North America expect to have 28 million people unemployed. That is not the sort of scenario one would draw as likely to make people more enthusiastic about taking migrants and refugees. Such predictions can lead to a challenge to build up in communities to migrant and refugee intakes, so we might face even greater problems in the future than we have. I think that aspect has to be looked at. Most of all, if we are going to do something deliberate and positive about the enormous problem of refugees in the world, we have to be consistent about our political attitudes in order to get these people settled back in their own countries.

We did not need all the fanfare and nonsense that the Prime Minister carried on with in relation to the 1980 Olympic Games. We needed a consistent opposition to the positioning of Soviet troops in Afghanistan. We still need it. It should be highlighted because of the way those people have been treated. We should tell President Reagan that he is wrong in his policy towards Latin America. We should support the French and the Mexicans in trying to bring about a political settlement in that area so as not to displace thousands more people. We should take the initiative wherever we can to see that the problems are solved in a political sense and not give the appearance, as we may have done in the past, of lifting everbody's hopes in Asia, Latin America or Africa that for all time we are going to be able to take increasing numbers of refugees. Our refugee program should not be aimed at telling the people who live in those unfortunate circumstances that Australia, the United States of America, France or Canada is the end of the rainbow. This is not the sort of policy that should be involved in rainbow-type politics. Leave that to Doug Anthony and Phil Lynch when they talk about their resources boom. When we are talking about people, we know that we can accept a certain number, but that it will not solve the problem. We should not lift their hopes too high. We should always be truthful with the people who come to live in this country about what we are able to do. We should be truthful with our own community about what we are doing and why we are doing it so that we can carry out the program successfully, but we should at all times take a consistent approach to the political problems that are causing such high numbers of people to be displaced from their own countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by congratulating the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) on a detailed, comprehensive and exceedingly thoughtful address to this House. May I also say that I commend very much what the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) said in his very thoughtful address and note in passing that he used his full allocation of 28 minutes, as no doubt the exuberance of the situation and his own interest in this most compelling subject drew him along.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to comment upon some aspects of the Minister's statement and upon one of two of the points raised by the honourable member for Port Adelaide. I welcome the decision which has been made to tighten the criteria and procedures for immigration and to determine eligibility on an individual basis. I think the determination of eligibility on an individual basis and the tightening of the criteria for refugees is a right and just decision. It is one which recognises that our capacity to take refugees is limited and that the humanitarian duty is owed to those who are genuine refugees. This House will be aware that not so long ago a boat-load of so-called refugees arrived on the shores of this country and after examination it was found that they had in fact come with carefully prepared stories to present to the Australian authorities, with the purpose of convincing the authorities that they were genuine refugees from Indo-China. The falsity of the stories was discovered and deportation orders were made. It is exactly that kind of situation that we should not have to face.

Moreover, no matter how generally compassionate one may feel towards people who wish for a variety of reasons to leave Indo-China-for example, Vietnam-but who are not themselves there subject to persecution but who wish to leave for economic reasons in order to have a more pleasant life and to resettle in a country which offers them much greater opportunities, we must always recognise that, if we allow those people to be automatically classified as refugees, we would be closing off the avenue for other people who are genuine refugees and also closing off from coming into this country other people who would apply under our migration program. It is perfectly plain and it is acknowledged by all sides that we can take only a limited number of people into this country. The honourable member for Port Adelaide made the point, and made it very forthrightly, that over the last six years the Government's record in the field of settlement of refugees in Australia has been an outstanding one. He said, and I agree with him entirely, that this has altered perceptions of Australians in South East Asia and elsewhere throughout Asia. That such an alteration in perception is necessary goes almost without saying when one considers that we are a country situated in South East Asia, and therefore it is simply not open to us to seek to pursue what used to be called the white Australia policy.

I agree entirely with the reasons put forward by the honourable member for Port Adelaide. I agree with what the Government has done in that area and I agree with the Opposition's attitude to the settlement of refugees and to the abolition of the white Australia policy. It may be said in passing that the Government's record of resettlement of refugees from Indo-China contrasts very favourably with that of some other countries. The honourable member for Port Adelaide instanced some. May I just instance one other country. Japan, I think, by July 1981 had resettled 1,510 refugees from Vietnam, which is hardly a major contribution to the difficulties that that problem occasions us all. The next point that I should like to comment upon is the break through. I hope that there has indeed been a break through in our relations with the Vietnam Government. I hope that that break through will mean that the migration of people from Vietnam will be dealt with in an orderly, humane and just fashion. It remains to be seen whether this is so, but the Minister and all those who have worked on this matter are to be commended for reaching what appears at this stage to be an agreement in principle.

Next, I should like to comment on the decision no longer to announce individual programs for particular groups. I think we all agree that this decision is correct because quite obviously not only are the expectations of particular groups raised, since they come to think that they have, as it were, a right to have an allocation of a certain number in every year, but also so long as that kind of program is in place it can mean that others, people who are refugees, people who need to be resettled throughout the world, who need resettlement here , will suffer. One knows that refugees are like tides. That they come and they go depending upon political events. A war occasions a vast outpouring of population because of the misery that people experience and we must be flexible enough to meet the infinite variety of changing circumstances so that where the need arises we can move to give some measures of assistance to the people who are in need. I noted this comment by the Minister in his statement:

I might add that while our global approach to these humanitarian programs gives us great flexibility there is no prospect of our extending other programs at the expense of our principal regional obligations regarding Indo-Chinese refugees.

I hope-I think I correctly understand the Minister-that that does not mean that there will be any iron-class allocation for Indo-Chinese refugees which must always be met, notwithstanding the other claims that may arise from time to time .

The third matter on which I should like to comment is the announcement of the decision that those who leave Soviet bloc countries should not be allowed in as a matter of right. I agree entirely with that decision. One only need look at what took place not so long ago when there was a great outpouring of so-called refugees from Cuba. When they arrived in Florida many of them were greeted as people who had fled from Castro's Cuba and from communism. But an examination of the facts turned up some rather interesting refugees. It seemed that Dr Castro may have been cleansing his gaols at the expense of the United States of America . Many of the refugees who arrived there were not refugees and would be of no assistance to the United States. They would be nothing but a detriment to the country. Obviously enough, just because people come from Soviet bloc countries it does not follow that they have an entitlement to be regarded as having a certain status which puts them ahead of others. I am glad, therefore, that that statement has been very clearly made and that it is very clearly part of Government policy.

The honourable member for Port Adelaide, whilst paying a generous tribute to the Government's resettlement program, did say that what one should look at is the need for political solutions. In principle, I entirely agree with him. But one knows how very difficult it is to impose political solutions in this world. One need only look at the confused state of South East Asia, where the refugee problem is most acute, to realise how difficult the imposition of political solutions is. One need only look at Africa, to see the wars which are in progress there, the civil wars which have caused such vast dislocation to the populations, to know how really impossible it is, often, in fact almost always, to achieve acceptable political solutions. Let us by all means aim for them, but let us remember the political realities. The honourable member referred in particular to Afghanistan and to the Government's record there. I think there are one or two points that the House should be aware of in that respect. First of all, the Government's direct relief aid to refugees from Afghanistan has to date been $12m. Secondly, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has never declared Afghans as refugees for resettlement. As I understand matters, repatriation is their wish and that is also the aim of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Of course repatriation would fit very well with the views espoused by the honourable member for Port Adelaide.

Let me conclude with two remarks. In the first place, there is an acknowledged limit on the number of refugees we can bring into this country. That limit depends upon a whole variety of circumstances. It depends upon the state of the economy. It depends upon the strain that bringing in refugees may impose on the social fabric of the country. As well, the number of refugees brought in every year affects the number of people who are entitled to apply and to be received in Australia as migrants. So one needs always to engage in a very fine exercise of judgment as between refugees and migrants, how many refugees we can accept at any one time and where those refugees should come from.

The last point I wish to make is that if we are to have a successful program in place for the assessment on an individual basis of refugee status, we need to have highly skilled staff. It is also necessary, if we are to get the maximum benefit out of this program, that we give the greatest amount of publicity to the Government's policy so that those overseas who may think that by one means or another they can get to this country and somehow be accepted as refugees when plainly they are not will realise that there is no easy entry into this country, except as a genuine refugee or as a migrant who is legally allowed into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was commenting on the unfeeling remarks by the honourable member for North Sydney in this debate on a statement on refugees delivered by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) this afternoon. I pointed out that to my mind he had shown a complete lack of compassion for refugees. Whenever the question of refugees, or immigration for that matter, is debated in this House, I usually try to participate in the discussion. The reason for that and why I am concerned about the plight of refugees can be summarised this way. Firstly, it is a huge problem . There are millions of people who risk their lives because all else has been already denied them. Some 14 million people are actual refugees at present. There is no doubt in my mind that there would be many millions more refugees if people had the chance to leave those countries which produce most of the refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I am concerned because these flights of men, women, children, infants , teachers, labourers, writers, simple peasants, doctors and shop keepers tell us more about the world in which we live than any other phenomenon. The willingness to risk life, to lose all one has ever had and accumulated, to leave family, friends and the land where one has been brought up is as accurate a thermometer of the health and sickness of the countries from which people flee and of the countries from which people do not flee, and is as precise an indicator of an unpleasant situation in those countries as are the degrees on a clinical thermometer an indicator of the temperature of a patient.

We have United Nations charters on human rights, we have the Helsinki agreements, decisions and definitions of human rights. When we look at it, how laborious, imprecise and partial a measure those charters are of the violations of decency. A measure so much more exact is available. Where do people flee from and where do they flee to? Basically it is a question of people voting with their feet. As far as I am concerned, any country which has a significant number of refugees, and especially a country where refugees are prevented from leaving, is a bad country. The country which accepts refugees, or which at least does not have refugees, is basically a country in which people accept the set-up in that country.

I turn for a couple of minutes to the position in my own electorate of Prospect to point out that the people of Prospect are concerned about refugees. We have large numbers of them. We have a large community of Russians or Ukrainians who came here straight after the war. We have about 6,000 Indo-Chinese refugees. We have a large number-some 2,000-of Assyrians, Christians from the Middle East and refugees from Iraq. We have a large number of South Americans from the Left, from the Right and from neither side. It is important often to remember that in areas such as South America the people who are refugees are quite apolitical. They know that whichever side is in power it is extremely unpleasant for them. They are dragooned by one side and by the other side into supporting them. I have contact with South Americans who are refugees from Allende's Chile and refugees now, obviously, from Pinochet's Chile. It is because such countries did not act in a particularly democratic fashion-in the case of Allende's Chile towards the end of the set-up there-that we have all these large numbers of people who have left. I point out to the House that 28 per cent of people in the electorate of Prospect were born overseas in non-English speaking countries. This compares with an average of 11 per cent for New South Wales, an average of about 10 per cent for Australia and of about one per cent for the electorate of Wannon. I emphasise those figures to show the lack of appreciation by such people as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for the problem of refugees. The Prime Minister does not take part in these sorts of debates but I am sure that the honourable member for North Sydney was stating the sort of position that the Prime Minister would adopt.

I deal now with the specific statement by the Minister. Basically, I do not disagree with the statement but I would like to raise a couple of points. The first one is that he refers in different parts of the statement, firstly, to refugees; secondly, to people who are eligible under special humanitarian programs; and, thirdly, to displaced persons. The Minister referred to the humanitarian program on the tenth page of the statement and to displaced persons on the twelfth page of his statement. I am not completely clear on what the clear cut definition is. I do not think it is as easy as just saying that one accepts the United Nations definition of refugees. On the fourth page of his statement the Minister states:
. . . as individuals, they-
That is, refugees-
commit themselves totally to this country for, unlike migrants, they know that there is no going back to their old home.

I do not think that is quite true. I think that at least some hope to go back to their own countries when they are free. It is hoped that a large number of those countries will become democracies and there will be no necessity to have refugees from those countries. On page 6 of the Minister's statement he deals with what could be called economic refugees. It is a term that I will deal with a little later. It is a term that I do not like. He said:

Many, perhaps most, people who become caught up in a mass movement can make only slight claims to having suffered persecution. Many people who voluntarily leave their country to take up residence elsewhere are motivated by a variety of different factors-economic reasons, the desire for change, family considerations or other reasons of a personal nature. In some cases the reasons for leaving may also include a dislike or abhorance of the political systems or ideology operating in their homeland. In some cases people may face some form of discrimination in their daily lives. Motivations to leave are often complex but unless these motivating factors are accompanied by a well-founded fear of persecution for reasons of race, religion, nationality or membership of a particular social group, or political opinion, refugee status should not apply.

I think that the position is not as nicely clear cut as that. If we go back about 40 years to the best known example of refugees to this century-I refer to the Jewish refugees from Germany or the political refugees from Germany-in many cases before 1938 or 1939 they would not have been considered to be refugees. Of course, that is what happened to them. In retrospect, it is quite clear that they were refugees but many countries did not treat them that way. It was considered that they were in no immediate risk and, in fact, they were in no immediate risk. There was no evidence in Germany at that time that they would be put in concentration camps or eliminated. I am talking about the mid to late 1930s before the War started when people outside Germany considered that they were not refugees.

The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) referred to a statement made by the Vietnamese Association of Australia last year. The Council of Vietnamese Organisations in New South Wales is based in my electorate. I had a statement incorporated in Hansard on 20 October last year. They made the point, that it is not easy to differentiate clearly between economic refugees and others. Other people have realised it. Going back to statements made in 1978, I noticed one by the Social Democrats, USA, sponsored by A. Philip Randolph, Honorary Chairman, Bayard Ruston, National Chairman and Carl Gershman, Executive Director. One of the points they made was:

The dropping of the distinction between 'economic' and 'political' refugees, a distinction that is sometimes used to relieve those who would normally assist political refugees from feeling any obligation toward those who have fled. The use of the 'economic' classification has even, in violation of the Universal Declaration on Human Rights, served as a justification for the forcible repatriation of refugees in some instances.

It is not simple to make that sort of distinction. The refugee problem turns on numbers. Australia cannot take all refugees, not even a large proportion, because this is simply not possible in domestic political terms. Nor can Australia take no refugees-as some advocate-because international pressures will not allow this and, as the boat people incidents indicate, refugees will come anyway. Our splendid isolation is a thing of the past. I do not think that is a bad thing. As far as refugees are concerned-I have had talks with the Minister and he has been co-operative-facts must be publicised, people must be told about it. I conclude with the last sentence of a letter which I received from the President of the Vietnam Association of Australia, Nguyen Anh Tuan, thanking me for a letter which I had written to the Sydney Morning Herald in support of the refugees:
Surely at a time when so much concern is being expressed about the treatment of whales, a little compassion can also be extended to human beings whose only crime is to prefer freedom to tyranny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman). I did not suggest-
—Does the honourable member wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.
—He may proceed to do so.

—I did not suggest that those who left Cuba were all demanding of sympathy. I would never make that suggestion.
