SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) said in his statement that this is the first comprehensive review of Australia's policies on refugee settlement since the establishment of the current machinery, which was set up in May 1977. The Minister added that the guiding principles of the review were those embodied in the Government's stated refugee policy of that date which dealt with the responsibility to admit refugees, the fact that the Australian Government was to decide who was to be admitted with the provision of assistance in special circumstances, and the fact that the interests of certain refugees might be better served by their being resettled elsewhere. It dealt also with the matter of regular aid to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party's position on immigration, refugees and deportation has, in some areas, common threads with the policies and statements expressed by the Minister. I wish to make a brief reference to Labor's policy on immigration generally, which reads:

A Labor Government will establish a National Population Council, to consider and make recommendations on the relationship between population growth, immigration, the economy, the environment and the quality of life.
The Council will be drawn from groups representing community, demographic, economic, environmental, industrial and social interests.

Labor supports immigration at a level which is consistent with the national interest and Australia's humanitarian obligations. Within the immigration programme family reunions must have a high priority.
The ALP-
When returned to government-

will establish consultative machinery between the States and Federal Government to determine the level of immigration intake and of Federal financial support to ensure the States can provide adequate facilities, services and opportunities for all new settlers.
Family reunion sponsored by Australian residents shall not require maintenance guarantees.

As negotiated with the United Nations High Commission for Refugees, the Australian Government after consultation with the States will select without discrimination on grounds of sex, politics, colour, race, creed or place of origin, and accept for permanent settlement, its fair share of the refugees being cared for by countries of first asylum.

Uninvited refugees seeking asylum in Australia as a country of first asylum should be cared for on behalf of the UN whilst arrangements are made through the United Nations High Commission for Refugees for their final settlement amongst member nations of the UN, including Australia.
Negotiations will be opened with the New Zealand Government to resolve problems of abuse of the present free entry in either direction.
That displays, again, a common thread with the attitudes that the Government has expressed on that question. The policy continues:
There will be no discrimination in the immigration policy or any other areas of policy on the grounds of race, nationality, politics, sex or creed.
There shall be no distinction between Australian citizens, whether born in Australia or overseas, in legal, social or political rights.

A right of appeal against deportation orders and denials of citizenship to an independent tribunal with judicial status and jurisdiction will be established. This Tribunal shall be presided over by a judge and composed of members drawn from a cross-section of the community.
A complete review of deportation procedures will be undertaken.

The common thread to which I have referred can clearly be seen. The Minister's statement concerning an arrangement with the Vietnamese Government, however limited, is nevertheless welcome. The point has been made that the Minister's speech was extremely long, but perhaps that is the kernel of his statement. The arrangement with the Vietnamese Government is welcome because it is an indication that this Liberal-National Country Party Government is apparently prepared to speak with that Government. However, one cannot ignore, or lightly pass over, our earlier involvement in and with Vietnam. That involvement, with the American involvement, created in Vietnam the very climate that has led to the departure of hundreds of Vietnamese from their own country. I speak of those who are often referred to as the boat people. The American war in Vietnam-in which unfortunately the Liberal-Country Party Government of the day involved us- left that country devastated on a staggering scale. In southern Vietnam alone, about 16 per cent of the population was either killed or wounded during the war and 57 per cent was made homeless between 1965 and 1974. Many roads and bridges were destroyed and agriculture was severely disrupted. Internal refugees swelled the cities and towns which provided employment, primarily through the military machines and the service industries. They lived also, unproductively, on the various types of foreign-primarily United States-economic assistance.

The sudden end of this war, which lasted 30 years, had a dislocating and destabilising impact. What happened in Vietnam occurred in many countries right throughout Europe. In fact, a breeding ground for potential refugees was created . It was a breeding ground that America and a Liberal-Country Party Government dragged Australia into. It is no use the Minister and others speakers talking of a humanitarian policy. It is no use looking for solutions to refugee problems. We need to start to look at the problems themselves. We need to avoid the creation of breeding grounds for refugees. We cannot undo that tragic war and the devastation of Vietnam but I believe we can do something to correct the evil of that war.

Let us look at the cost, because inevitably everything is looked at in economic terms. The cost to Australia was 496 young soldiers killed in Vietnam along with 2,800 injured. The Fraser Government promised $6m for a reconstruction program but that was terminated for a political reason. It was convenient for the Government to use such a reason to take away that paltry sum of $6m in reconstruction aid to Vietnam. It cost even the United States, and some 50,000 people were killed. God knows how many were injured. The total cost probably never will be known. The reconstruction aid promised by the American Government was in the vicinity of $4 billion. It was a promise never fulfilled. This country and the present Government had best turn their attention to the problems that cause refugees to have to look to other countries, that cause them to leave their homes.

On the question of South America, the Minister has said that more consideration will be given to refugees from that area. That is a statement welcomed by this side of the House. I point out that one of the problems in the past with immigration from South America was the failure to have sufficient offices of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs located in South America.

In regard to the third matter, deportation, we have had a number of situations that were not the kind of situations that one likes to see and that one would not see if political considerations did not come into it. I refer in particular, to the bikini girl incident. We have seen in the past people who, for their own political gain, have been allowed to stay in Australia while others have been forced to leave. I refer in particular to a case that I had to take up with the Department and with the Minister. It was the case of an 18 year old Greek seaman . Had that young lad been from a communist country-perhaps he should have worn a red bikini-he may have been given much more consideration, but he was not. He wanted to stay in Australia with his relatives. He was unceremoniously dumped in the Adelaide gaol.

Adelaide-I hope the Minister takes note of this-has no proper detention centre for people who are about to be deported. I understand there are adequate facilities in both Sydney and Perth but the facilities in Adelaide are a disgrace. The people who are forced by one circumstance or another to be incarcerated have to spend their time in the Adelaide gaol. The gaol has reached such a state that it is being pulled down; it is not even good enough for criminals. The proper approach to this should be one in which the politics of the situation are not given the weight that they have been in the past, and those who have to be deported should be given proper facilities and treated not as criminals but as people who are not to be allowed to stay in Australia. The detention centre in Adelaide is certainly no fit place for people to be incarcerated.

We have no great difference of opinion with the Minister in regard to the direction which his portfolio has taken. That is acknowledged and the Minister's work is acknowledged but I reiterate that we should be turning our attention to our responsibilities throughout the country, and throughout the world, to try to avoid situations where people in their own countries find that they have to become refugees. I believe that our involvement in Vietnam created a situation in which hundreds of thousands of people had to leave their own country. Whilst we might talk about humanitarian policies and approaches, I think it is a case of closing the stable door after the horse has bolted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating a statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) concerning changes to our arrangements for the selection of refugees under our refugee settlement policy. I welcome the statement from the Minister and I note that a principal part of it refers to the tightening of the refugee selection criteria and procedures for all programs with the particular objective of excluding from refugee entry those persons who do not meet the criteria allowed for in the United Nations convention. The Minister in his statement made particular reference to the fact that appropriate authorities had been consulted in the making of these changes, especially the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make some comment about that because I believe that Australian authorities have a very high reputation amongst the personnel of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. That is something we should guard very jealously. I have discovered in visits that I have made to some refugee camps in South East Asia and in discussions I have had with UNHCR personnel that the work of Australian selection officers and the criteria that we apply have been highly regarded. It is fair to say that Australian policies and procedures have been regarded as being in advance of many other countries. I have heard only one criticism from the United Nations officials with whom I have spoken in some of those areas regarding Australian procedures and personnel. That criticism has been basically along the lines that Australian selection officers in the refugee camps seem to be a little too bureaucratic, that they seem to want to apply criteria very strictly without enough flexibility to accord with particular family circumstances that may arise in individual cases.

I suggest that the other side of that coin is that the Australian selection officers are known to apply the rules very strictly, very fairly and very evenly . They are not subject to approaches from people who want special consideration because of their background, their political attitude or whatever, I think this is a reputation to guard very jealously. When I put this to the UNHCR officials they agreed that Australian selection officers were not subject to corruption; that they were not subject to being bought off; that it was not possible to gain entry to Australia by currying favour in a financial sense or another sense with an Australian selection officer. That is a reputation that we should guard very jealously. It is a reputation that is not shared by all countries in the refugee selection and settlement area.

I was particularly pleased to note that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in this statement outlined the fact that the Government has now reached an agreement with Vietnamese authorities about the manner in which applications from Vietnam for people to re-join family members in Australia can be processed in an orderly fashion. I think that for many of us in this House this has been a problem area for some time. I certainly have had drawn to my attention several cases of applications having been made and nominations having been put by relatives in Australia in support of relatives in Vietnam, seeking to bring about family reunions. Because of the absence of an agreement between the Australian Government and the Vietnamese Government about appropriate procedures by which family reunions can be brought about there have been cases of people waiting, for years in some cases, for some action to be taken. I welcome this development and I hope that within two or three months, in line with what has been suggested by the Minister in his statement, we will see some of these family reunions taking place. I will certainly be taking the opportunity to raise afresh some of the cases which involve family reunions between people in Australia and in Vietnam that I have drawn to the Minister's attention in the last few years.

I want to comment on some suggestions that have been made that on occasions preference is given to various applicants for settlement in Australia on the basis of their political belief or background. I think that this is a criticism that certainly cannot be levelled against this Minister in particular. Indeed, it would be fair to say that he has been criticised, one might say, by some people for committing the opposite sin, for not giving enough attention to the political colour of the country of origin of the people who in some instances have applied for refugee status. I think we must realise that in many respects it is very easy for people to claim refugee status and to see that as an easy way in which they can circumvent the normal procedures to gain entry to Australia as permanent residents.

The thought seems to be that if people can in some way jump ship, overstay a visitor's visa, or put in a complaint about their lifestyle in their home country, they will be given preferential treatment over people who have applied and whose applications have been considered in the normal way, but whose applications have been rejected. In the days when Australia was seeking very large immigration intakes, when we were looking for figures of 180,000 or close to 200,000 immigrants a year, when we were looking for sheer numbers to staff industries in Australia, it may have been possible to give that consideration. However, in circumstances in which we face up to one million inquiries a year from around the world regarding settlement in Australia-the latest intake figure is slightly in excess of 100,000, I think about 111,000, in the last financial year-we must acknowledge that hundreds of thousands of people each year put in an application, have it considered, find it rejected and accept that decision in good grace.

I think that under those circumstances anyone who seeks to circumvent the normal procedures by placing himself or herself on Australian soil under unusual circumstances and then claims refugee status should have that claim examined very closely. I do not think that we should accept it automatically on the basis of the political colour of the country from which that person comes. After all, in many of those countries with regimes which we find abhorrent and quite contrary to our democratic standards we are nevertheless seeking to develop normal relations, we are nevertheless seeking to bring about normal family reunions because of people who are already here who nominate people in those countries. I suggest that it would make our position much more difficult if we entertained without due consideration applications from people who came here on visitor's visas and then sought to circumvent the normal immigration requirements.

It would make it much more difficult for the Minister to make representations to ambassadors from various countries in Eastern Europe and other places where there are governments with which we very strongly disagree if we were to put him in a position of saying 'Well, we will accept anyone who comes here and jumps ship or in some other way circumvents the normal requirements of our immigration policy. But forget about that. Nevertheless, we would like you to give special consideration to these other cases that have been drawn to our attention'. I think in those circumstances we would find that special consideration would not be granted by those countries, that the opportunities to bring about genuine family reunion when there are strong compassionate circumstances would not exist any more. So I believe that the evenhanded, fair, but firm approach which this Minister is taking on behalf of the Government is one that should be strongly supported by both sides of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) for this opportunity to speak. I have a special interest in immigration. I would be probably the only one in this House who came here as an adult migrant with a non-English speaking background. Of course, being a migrant I feel very strongly about the issues which were canvassed here today, especially the issue of family reunion. In the short time given to me-I do not want to take advantage of that and speak for too long-I would like to mention several issues. Some of them may be contradictory. On one side I may advocate that we should take more Polish refugees than the Minister is ready to take today because I know the plight of the people who are sitting in Australian camps waiting for somewhere to go to start a new life. Even though the Minister said that many of them want to stay near their homelands, which I accept, there are just as many who want to get as far away from those homelands as possible because of the turbulent times the Poland and Eastern and Western European economies are going through. They want to start a new life. I think that we can afford them that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I am also conscious that our humanitarian commitment and other commitments to take refugees take a big slice out of our ability to accept as many migrants as possible for family reunion.

Let me get back to the refugee situation. We are somewhat single-minded-and I am critical of the Minister in this regard- as far as that situation is concerned. It is true that we have a responsibility to Asia and to Asian migration. It is true that we are responsible to some extent for the Indo- Chinese refugee situation. We went into Vietnam and we created a situation which led to extremes in that country. If we had not assisted in intervention in Vietnam there would have been a national front in government-Communist or non- Communist-and many more of the people chased out by the extremist regime would still be in Vietnam today. So we have an obligation, and I admit that obligation . At the same time I would like to see many more people coming here on a family reunion basis. Like other members of parliament, although probably a bit more so , I am approached by people who are unable to bring their sisters, brothers or close family members to this country from overseas. It happens that very often half of a family lives in Australia and the other half lives in Pakistan or India. My colleague the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) said that we have got rid of the White Australia policy. I tend to disagree with him somewhat, in that we have not completely got rid of that policy. I know that we receive no more than 500 migrants a year from India. Yet there are 20,000 applications from people who want to come to this country. Most of these applications are made on a family reunion basis. Most of the applicants have mothers, fathers, sisters or other family members who have settled successfully in this country-people who speak English, people who play cricket, people who can fit in here. Yet we have closed the barrier. I often wonder whether we have done this because something is wrong with their colour, and we do not want to admit it. I think we should leave much more room for decisions to be made on a family reunion basis. It should not matter from where people come, whether from South America, England or India. We should let in people whose families have already settled successfully in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MACPHEE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that I allowed the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) to say a few words because what he said illustrates the whole difficulty of this area. My colleague and old friend the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) said that he thought that the 28 minutes I took to read my speech was too long. Frankly, the reason I spoke for so long was to try to get across the complexity of this area. Yet, I think the speeches of the honourable member for Hotham, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) illustrated the fact that some members still do not understand. If they fail to understand how can their constituents understand?

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hotham said that some of his points might be contradictory, and indeed they were. I respect his sincerity as I do that of his two colleagues whom I have named. But, with respect, they are all heart and eventually somebody has to face up to some crunch questions. There has to be some rational basis for working through our humanitarianism. As the honourable member for Port Adelaide said so well, we cannot take everybody. This is the last continent in which people can start a new life. We cannot take everybody who is displaced; there has to be some basis for taking people. He also rightly said that for the most part we have to find some way of settling their problems another way. He also said we are a small country in terms of influence and therefore the political role which we can play is going to be limited. There will be arguments on both sides of the House and within both sides of the House as to the role we should play. But we cannot take everyone who is displaced or, to use the words of the honourable member for Hotham, everyone who wants to work to start a new life. This is the last continent in which people can start a new life unless they can learn to live with the penguins in the Antarctic. The honourable member for Hotham says that we can afford to let them start that new life. Can we?

Members on both sides of the House are concerned about the labour market and another old friend of mine, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), will be raising a matter of public importance on this matter. We are all concerned about the labour market. We cannot go on with an unlimited flow of people no matter how anguished their personal situation may be. We have to consider the impact upon our own economy. The honourable member for Hotham has said we should take some more Poles. There is something very significant in what he said. He is reported in a suburban newspaper-the newspaper does not actually circulate in my area but someone has sent me a copy of it-as saying that we were taking only a thousand Poles or something or other. I hope my statement has put that to rest. Had he read my Press releases he would know that was not so. We have a global objective for the reasons that I outlined and which are supported by the Opposition. The honourable member pointed out the turbulent times in Eastern and Western Europe. That is so-there are turbulent times throughout the world economy. This economy is not without its difficulties as the Opposition reminds us and as we are well aware. Are we now to start taking everyone else who finds himself the victim of turbulent times?

The honourable member for Hotham also said that we would have had fewer Vietnamese refugees if Australia had not joined the Americans in intervening in the Vietnam War. A number of people on both sides of the House had views at the time of that intervention. I was not a member of the House at that time but I had a view. I maintained the view that the intervention was anti-historical. I might say that the honourable member's interpretation is just as questionable on historical grounds. The history of Vietnam is that there are three Vietnams. The civil war in Vietnam was one in which there was external intervention from the Soviets as well as the Americans. In fact, historically the north was more likely to conquer the south and the centre squeezed between the two. As a result there would still have been refugees. It does not really matter much how the problem came about. We in this Parliament and in this country in 1982 cannot do much about amending the wrongs of other regimes. What we can do is do our best internationally to bring about sensible political solutions and where we can on a humanitarian basis assist displaced persons, so we must. When they are displaced we have to determine the degree of persecution or discrimination. That is what we are concerned about. The whole point of my lengthy statement, which contained a measured amount of repetition, was to try to point out why and on what criteria we make certain distinctions between refugees and special humanitarian cases.

The honourable member for Prospect made an equally humane but equally irrational contribution to this debate. In the course of his remarks he was unfair to my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) who in fact made what I thought was a very rational contribution. The honourable member for North Sydney is not to my knowledge, and certainly from what he said today, a WASP. He gave an example of the Cubans, some of whom were identifiable as people from criminal institutions. This does not in fact mean that they were not refugees under the current regime in Cuba but they certainly were not all necessarily refugees. The honourable member was trying to illustrate the fact that not all displaced persons are refugees. That was the whole point of this contribution. It is fine for us all to have humanity but we also need to have a little bit of rationality and this is the purpose of the statement.

I am indebted to the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) for trying to return some rationality to the debate. The honourable member said that not all of the people who come to this country can be properly classified as refugees. I might also say that not all of those persons who place themselves in neighbouring countries poised ready to come to our shores are refugees. I read in the newspaper some more bleeding heart stuff about a family which went to Bangkok from Warsaw. The family said that it was advised to go there because it was easier to be processed as refugees in Bangkok than it is in Vienna. I do not know who gave that advice. Certainly it was not an Australian official. That has been verified. That family will have to be treated on the same criteria as I outlined today. These criteria apply to all persons claiming to be refugees, whether they are in Vienna, Pulau, Bidong or Sydney.

The honourable member for Casey made an important point concerning numbers. He mentioned the devolution or evolution of policy-devolution partly from the United Nations and evolution within our own experience. It is an assessment of needs and competing priorities. If there is one commodity which we are not short of in this world, it is refugees or displaced persons. Machinery has had to be evolved domestically and internationally to resolve those problems. It sounds clinical but believe me, Mr Deputy Speaker, when one is in the situation of having to make decisions about competing priorities, one has to be as rational as one can be. If that sounds cynical and too rational, it is a better alternative than being subjected to trial by media. People who want to fast in a city square in Bangkok or somewhere else are not necessarily to be given priority over somebody else who has patiently waited in line and patiently asked to be processed. It might make us unpopular and sound as if we are callous and heartless but, when one looks at the sheer numbers involved-the purpose of my lengthy statement was to illustrate that-I believe that what we are doing is fair and reasonable.

This has been a limited debate. Lengthy though it might have been, it was limited in ambit. We cannot cover all of the political solutions and we cannot redress all of the past wrongs. We can only deal with human flotsam and jetsam in the most rational way and compare the degree of discomfort, persecution and discrimination as well as safeguarding the interests of people living here, often born of migrant origins and who are competing for jobs. Looking at the interests of others who want to migrate here and make a contribution is never easy. The lines are never easily drawn. We are doing our best.

The honourable member for Hindmarsh spoke about a Greek seaman who wanted to stay in Australia because he had relatives here. Goodness me! As I said in my statement, we are attracting about a million tourists a year, most of whom have friends or relatives here. When they come here they all think that it is a nice place in which to live. As I said in my statement, we have no policy if we are to be governed by those kinds of considerations. The honourable member for Hindmarsh said that if this seaman had been from a communist country or wore a red bikini he could have stayed. That is not fair. I have gone to great lengths to try to explain the case by case analysis. The honourable member can disagree on what he knows of a certain case. I said on one occasion not long ago that I might not have come to the same conclusion as my predecessors regarding one or two cases, including the red bikini girl and the ballerina. The fact is that the Minister responsible and the committee which advises him do their best. Most of the information given is confidential and must remain so. When comparisons are made publicly they are made on less information than is ordinarily available to the Minister and the committee. I think that what honourable members and their constituents have to recognise is the fact that there are endless numbers of displaced persons around the world-at least 10 million to 16 million-not all of whom are called refugees by the United Nations, not all of whom are even marked as being people of concern, but all of whom are suffering great inconvenience. Not all of these people can be accommodated by Australia.

I return to a question which was raised by several speakers in the debate relating to mass population outflows. In conjunction with international agencies and other governments we have been trying to take measures which are designed to curb mass outflows. We have tried to work through the United Nations in support of an initiative of the Federal Republic of Germany to examine the causes of mass outflows. We co-sponsored a United Nations resolution to set up a working group, the membership of which we are seeking to expand. We are seeking to study through that membership the causes, means of prevention of mass outflows and to try to devise machinery by which we can ameliorate the conditions of the people involved in those outflows. Nothing involving those dislocations is easy and nothing that we do will ever do more than touch on marginal aspects of the problem.

When the honourable member for Port Adelaide began his response to my statement he said that if we could do something more internationally by way of political initiatives we would be making a bigger contribution. He is correct. As far as the Polish situation or any other situation that exists in the world is concerned, this Government stands ready to initiate discussions when we believe the time is right, to take part in them if somebody else initiates them and, as we have been patiently doing-certainly during the whole of this calendar year and since 13 December when martial law was imposed-to exchange cables with all governments of similar democratic persuasions to see what we can do that is best for the people involved. This is one of the contradictions referred to by the honourable member for Hotham. He apparently wants to set some competing and extravagant ceiling for taking more Poles and in making a virtue of that we would be sanctioning martial law. Australia, the United States of America, West Germany or any other Western nation are not in the business of doing that. We have tried to take into account what the Poles themselves want. Less than half of the Poles living in Vienna-that is where the overwhelming concentration of Poles live outside Poland-have asked for resettlement in another country. They want the chance, as the honourable member for Port Adelaide acknowledged, to work out for themselves in an unpanicked way what is best for them and their families.

There are lots of reasons incorporated in my statement, as well as those which I have mentioned, for leaving things as they are. We have not set an upper target. If martial law is further imposed, instead of being relaxed, and if a need is perceived internationally to do something further, we will respond in the same spirit and to the same kind of degree that we have. We will share our international obligations. In respect of South America we intend to send again a senior official there to look at the situation. I do share some of the concerns expressed that we are not taking as many people as one would expect we might. I have said that before. Two years ago we sent the then Deputy Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I hope that we will be able to send the present Deputy Secretary to examine the situation at first hand and to report to me. I can only repeat what I said in my statement: Most refugees have traditionally gone to Western Europe and North America. Unless the barriers there are really put down, they will continue to seek asylum in these countries rather than here. But we are open to take them. Those who have come have settled well and we would welcome more of them. I conclude by referring to a couple of substantial remarks by the Opposition shadow Minister, the honourable member for Port Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The further sharp deterioration in unemployment in Australia, and the responsibility of the Federal Government for this situation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This discussion deals with a matter of overwhelming importance for the people of Australia. One would hope that in the light of the election results on Saturday in Lowe and Western Australia that this Government would do two related things: Firstly, that it would stop the ludicrous and obscene ritual in which it engages each month of trying to pick one element or other out of the statistics and to confect some fantasy which puts an unrealistically favourable perspective on the employment and unemployment situation in this country; and, secondly-and as I say, relatedly-that the Government would accept that it has been obstinately wrong-headed in its economic diagnosis and prescriptions and that it would now move positively to undertake policies and programs calculated to improve what has developed into both an economic disaster and a social tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me in the first place spend some little time establishing what is the factual situation. Looking at the overall unemployment picture, the facts are: We had a total of 482,600 people out of work in February 1982 or, in percentage terms, 7 per cent of the labour force. This figure represents a substantial increase of 58,500, or an increase of 14 per cent over the level for the previous February, when the unemployment rate was 6.3 per cent. It is the highest unemployment rate for three years, and it is the highest level of unemployment ever recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

Much of the deterioration has been among full time job seekers. The level of full time joblessness has jumped to 404,500 or an unemployment rate of 7 per cent. This figure is 46,100 greater than that in February 1981. It is the first time that the level has passed 400,000 and it is the highest rate for three years. In February 1976, soon after the Fraser Government took office, the total unemployment rate was 342,000 or only 5.4 per cent of the labour force, compared with the 7 per cent which it is now. In absolute terms, that is an increase of 41 per cent in the level over that period, which indicates a very substantial deterioration after six years in office of the Fraser Government-a government which pledged itself to restore full employment.

Those are the figures in regard to those who are recorded as unemployed. Hidden unemployment has risen dramatically since 1974-75 and now accounts for at least a further 400,000 people who want jobs but who have stayed out of the labour force because of the persistent lack of job opportunities. In other words, taking the recorded figures together with the hidden figures, the actual rate of unemployment, or the imbalance between the number of jobs available and the number of those who would want to work if work were available, is probably over 12 per cent. Moreover, the average duration of unemployment has risen dramatically from around 13 weeks in 1975 to over 30 weeks during 1981. Even more revealing, in 1975 only 19.3 per cent of unemployment benefit payments were claimed by those who had been unemployed for six months or more, but by 1981 this had risen to almost 41 per cent.

On all the evidence, things are going to get worse. The Government itself, in its Budget papers, predicts increasing unemployment during 1981-82. The Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research predicts an average unemployment level of over 460,000, or 6.6 per cent, by the second half of 1982, compared with 386,400, or 5.7 per cent, during the comparable period of 1981. The Victorian Chamber of Manufactures predicts a persistent 7 per cent unemployment rate by 1983.

So much for the general figures about unemployment, recorded and hidden. Let me turn to the situation in regard to youth unemployment. The February level of 136 ,100 unemployed teenagers looking for full time work represented 20.1 per cent as an unemployment rate; or, putting it in very simple terms, it meant that one in five of teenagers who were looking for full time work could not get it. This figure is a 7 per cent jump from the February 1981 level, when the unemployment rate was 18.6 per cent. In the late 1975 and early 1976 period, the figure was between 70,000 and 80,000 unemployed teenagers looking for full time work. That was then an unemployment rate of between 13 per cent and 14 per cent, compared with what is now 20 per cent.

So much for youth unemployment. I move to an area which these days is sometimes neglected too much-unemployment in the older age groups. We rightly look at the problem in respect of young people; we tend to overlook the problem in the older groups. It is not just youth who are affected; this is spread throughout the age spectrum. The major recent increases in unemployment have occurred largely among those aged 20 years and older. In fact, 81 per cent of the annual increase in full time unemployment to February 1982-that is, February on February-has been in the 20 years and over group, and the deterioration in unemployment over the previous three months to February 1982 occurred almost entirely among the adult age groups.

The duration of unemployment experienced is also far worse among the older age groups. The average duration of unemployment among adults-those 20 years of age and over-is twice as great as that among teenagers. There is in fact a very strong relationship between increasing age and the length of unemployment experience. For instance, the Australian Bureau of Statistics' labour force data for January reveal the following average duration situation among various age groups: For teenage unemployment, the average duration of unemployment is 17 weeks. For the 25 to 34-year-olds it is 29 weeks. For the 45 to 54-year-olds it is 52 weeks. Taking the top bracket, those aged between 60 and 64, it is 101 weeks.

Also, it is among the older age groups that the incidence of hidden unemployment has hit particularly hard. This is shown by the recent studies by Stricker and Sheehan in Melbourne and by the Social Welfare Research Institute of the University of New South Wales. Looking at the receipt of unemployment benefit, we find that it has been among the 25 to 44 years age group that the greatest upsurge has occurred. Over 31 per cent of unemployment benefit claimants are currently in this age bracket, compared with only 26.4 per cent during 1975. That has been reflected in the fact that the proportion claimed by those under 21 years old has fallen over the same period from 41.5 per cent to 36.6 per cent. The concept of the young dole bludger was always objectionable and not based in fact. On those figures it is clear, now that I have explained them, that we have this phenomenon of unemployment spreading right through the age structure.

Of course, I have been talking about unemployment. I have given the factual situation-unembellished; factual. That reflects what has been happening on the other side-what has been happening to employment growth. Without appearing to state what is, perhaps, too obvious, I must say that the slump in the growth rate in employment opportunities is, of course, the main cause of the worsening unemployment situation. Let us look at what has happened. Annual employment growth has slumped from around 3 1/2 per cent in the September quarter of 1980 to the miserable level of 1 1/2 per cent or less over the past three months. Looking at the simple basic economic facts, one can understand what is happening now and what is in prospect. That sort of growth in employment, 1 1/2 per cent, is totally insufficient to cover the basic economic factors of growth in the labour force and of what happens in respect of productivity. If we have about a 2 per cent increase in the labour force and a 2 per cent increase in productivity, we must have a 4 per cent growth in output just to keep up with those basic factors, without starting in any way to cut into the backlog of people who are currently unemployed.

The employment situation in respect of teenagers has slumped dramatically since the middle of last year. I was referring previously to the unemployment situation, but I now go to what is happening in regard to the actual employment area. What has happened since the middle of last year is that, on an annual basis, teenage employment has been falling by increasing amounts since August of last year, and by December 1981 the collapse over the year-December on December- was 21,500 and by January 1982 this had worsened to 23,200.

Let me make the point simply. That means that in January 1982 there were 23,200 fewer teenagers in full time employment than there were in the previous January. I said that that was in full time employment; that has been in total teenage employment. But most of that decline has been in full time job opportunities, with almost three-quarters of the decline being in the full time area.

I have been as dispassionate as I possibly can. I have not tried to embellish. I have tried to put before this House what the actual situation is, looking at both the unemployment side of the coin and at what has happened to employment growth. Now, clearly, to look for the responsibility in this matter, it would not be honest for me to say that one can explain every facet of unemployment in this country simply by blaming the Government for its misguided economic policies. I accept that in this country, and in other countries, certain basic forces are operating which make it more difficult to regain a full employment situation. I acknowledge that, but I do say without any equivocation that the Government's economic policies have been to a very considerable extent responsible for much of the difficulties. The overall economic strategy of this Government has undoubtedly contributed to the situation. Attempts by the Government to suppress inflation by reducing the Budget deficit and clamping down on growth of the money supply have restrained economic growth and have limited the availability of new employment opportunities. The only recent instance of reasonable employment growth in this country was during the second half of 1980. That was precisely because in that period the Federal Government deliberately relaxed its tight economic policies because it knew that it was coming up to an election and it wanted to have a more optimistic and rosy economic situation. As soon as the election was over the reins were put on again and we had the resumption of the contractionary policies.

It is not good enough for any of the Government's spokesmen to say that the Government is right and that there is no question about the correctness of its policies. There has been increasing criticism of this Government's strategies and policies from a very wide number of reputable sources over recent times. I will cite some of them. There is the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, Professor J. O. N. Perkins also of the Melbourne University, and, most recently, Dr Peter McCawley of the Australian National University. The Federal Government, by its own budgetary admissions has acknowledged the unsatisfactory contractionary impact of its monetary and fiscal policies.

It has argued that reduced Government intervention and suppression of inflation are necessary pre-requisites for the stimulation of job growth in the private sector. This Government has had more than six years to test its theories. That is long enough for anyone, but they simply have not worked. The situation has significantly worsened as a result of them. It is time, on the evidence and on the basis of the criticisms of informed and responsible economists outside the Government, for a change of course. Let me make it quite clear that I go from the inadequacies of the general economic policies of this Government to be very critical of specific manpower policies which have also been totally deficient. I ask the House to remember these figures: The amount of expenditure by the Fraser Government on all manpower training and support programs had fallen in real terms by over 50 per cent between 1975-76 and 1980-81. Even with the increased Budget allocation of 1981-82, the decline in real terms over the life of this Fraser Government has been 44 per cent. That is a 44 per cent reduction in real terms on total expenditure in respect of manpower training and support programs. Individual programs have been correspondingly inadequate.

I conclude by saying that the time has come, as I have said before, to stop the nonsense of asking 'What is the cost of undertaking job creation programs?' The real question for this society to ask is: 'What is the cost of not undertaking these programs?' This country can no longer tolerate or afford these heartless and mindless policies which have brought about this economic and social tragedy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) with great interest. It was not until the latter part of his address tonight that he was more characteristic of the person that he is and is known to be. He had made a thoughtful and considered contribution to that stage. But, at that stage, he then went off onto the job creation schemes, for which his predecessors were well known. It is probably worth recalling the great impact that the socialist dream had. It is worth remembering that the Opposition , when in power, created, certainly in the Regional Employment Development scheme, 64,000 jobs at a cost of some $60m, but not one of those jobs was permanent. That is worth remembering after listening to the contribution tonight . The Opposition created 64,000 temporary and false jobs and in roughly the same period--
—Have you any facts to support that? How do you know that?
—Total employment actually dropped.
—Where are your facts? You have no facts to support that.

—It is a pity the honourable member for Burke is not employed. Full time employment dropped by 18,000 at the same time. As employment went down, while the Opposition was artificially creating these jobs, unemployment doubled. What a record! This is the socialist objective that we have been hearing so much about tonight.
—What are you talking about? I didn't say anything about the socialist objective. You are going roughly, aren't you?

—I was roughly referring to what the socialists did in the 1972-75 period under the RED scheme. In relation to these matters it is worth recalling that trade unions these days do not give much concern to the unemployed. They give concern to the employed. Therefore, in this nation at present those people are the great unprotected and un-looked-after by the trade union movement, which makes judgments in relation to a 1960 economy under the totally changed circumstances of 1980 and in which the whole economic environment has altered. If honourable members listened to the Australian Broadcasting Commission news bulletin tonight, they will recall that the great New South Wales Premier has decided that, because of industrial unrest, it is likely that that State will move to a four-day working week and that power zoning will be introduced. This is a direct result of industrial unrest.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to do anything else but say that the Government does not deny that the preliminary figures of unemployment released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics last week were disappointing. It was not a good result. However, there is no cause and this is not the time for panic. The movement in unemployment was not unexpected. The Government has acknowledged, and it is readily evident, that the pace of economic activity and the rate of employment growth moderated in the second half of last year. There was a tendency for this to be reflected in the unemployment figures late last year. The issue is not whether there has been an easing in the labour market. There has been, and this is consistent with the expectations at the time of the August Budget. More important is the clear and urgent need to place these estimates in the context of the broader economic and labour market conditions in Australia and overseas and to consider the meaningful and appropriate policy responses open to the Government. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates of unemployment for 1982 indicate 404,500 people, or 7 per cent of the labour force, were unemployed and looking for full time work in February. The month of February together with January and December traditionally records higher levels of unemployment than other months. The influx of school leavers into the labour market and the closing down of industry and commerce over the Christmas-January period are the major causes-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—Further, it needs to be kept in mind that the unemployment estimates are derived from the monthly production population samples.
—There is an explosion in youth unemployment. It is up 70 per cent from February to February.
—It is very loud around here, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Yes. Order! The House will come to order.

—Too much reliance should not be placed on one month's figures. Any attempt to forecast the future by extrapolating the estimates for February is therefore clearly inappropriate and mischievous. More importantly, the figures should be considered in the context of the gains in employment which have occurred as a result of the Government's policies. In the 12 months to January 1982, employment grew by 102,200 or 1.6 per cent. In the two years since January 1980, the employment growth was substantial, totalling some 242,000 or 4 per cent employment growth. A particularly encouraging aspect of these figures has been the growth in full time employment, which has accounted for 85 per cent of the overall growth in employment. While employment growth has moderated in line with economic growth in recent months, solid gains have been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: An important area of concern about unemployment in Australia has been the extent to which it impinges on the teenager. While the overall unemployment rates are still too high, the estimates indicate the teenage labour market has fared relatively better than the other segments. The priority and emphasis which the Government has placed on youth through a variety of training and work experience schemes and support for apprenticeship training has undoubtedly been an important influence.

The latest unemployment estimates provide a timely reminder of the importance of ensuring that the economic and unemployment achievements of recent years are not squandered. In particular they emphasise that employment growth is inevitably linked to economic performance. Australia's economic performance compares more than favourably with most overseas countries. For example in 1981 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries recorded a growth rate of a little over one per cent, whereas Australia managed a growth rate of 3 per cent. Indeed in the last two years economic growth in Europe and North America has virtually come to a standstill with high and rising unemployment. It is hardly surprising that these overseas trends have begun to influence and constrain Australia's economic performance. Australia is a major trading nation and it is quite impossible for this country to isolate itself completely from world economic circumstances and pressures. The high interest rates and the reappraisal and deferment of some resource projects provide examples of this economic interdependence. The level of wages and overall labour costs have a vital bearing on Australia's continued economic recovery. It is being increasingly recognised in this country that the greatest threat to healthy employment prospects and, indeed, to sustained economic growth, derives from excessive wage demands. In this regard, I would refer honourable members to the remark of the former member for Melbourne Ports, Mr Frank Crean, who saw quite clearly, at a time of burgeoning wage demands in 1974 that one man's pay increase is another man's job. The experience in Australia in the first half of the 1970s and in a number of other countries provides ample evidence of this nexus, as do the unemployment estimates released last week.

The significant wage increases agreed upon over recent months, the levels of industrial disruption and the large number of hefty wage claims currently in prospect have obviously influenced the ability and willingness of employers to maintain and expand employment opportunities. Since the end of indexation we have witnessed over half the work force obtaining wage increases, some of which were considerable. The accelerating rate of wage increases must not continue, as wages spiral must be avoided, otherwise, not only are the employment prospects of the existing unemployed and school leavers at risk but also so is the job security of many Australians now in employment. The irresponsible and selfish conduct of those who put their own short term interests ahead of the nation as a whole will lead to an uncertain environment for investment and development and dampen the prospects for strong employment growth. Those who press for excessive wage rises and shorter hours and who do not hesitate to use the strike weapon to push their claims, would do well to pause and consider the effect of their actions on the community, particularly the unemployed and the school leavers who will find it much harder to get and keep a job.

This then is the context in which the unemployment estimates should be considered. The Opposition has again put forward a strategy based on expansionary fiscal and monetary policies and massive job creation. The proposed panacea is not new, nor is it inappropriate. However, by the way of response, I would like to draw on the communique released following the recent ministerial level meeting of the OECD Manpower and Social Affairs Committee attended by the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown). The meeting emphasised that efforts to combat unemployment could be successful only in the framework of effective anti-inflationary policy. The communique further recognised that labour costs must be kept in check in the current circumstances and that the encouragement of investment provides the essential basis for employment growth. These issues-I might add that the communique reflects the views of employment ministers of a variety of political persuasions-are exactly those aspects which this Government has emphasised are of fundamental importance to bouyant and sustainable economic growth. The Opposition's proposals are, in most instances, diametrically opposed to these widely held and internationally recognised views. A larger public sector and a lax fiscal and monetary policy will only reintroduce in a far more accentuated form the imbalances and rampant inflation evident in the Australian economy in the mid-1970s. The task of managing the economy in the present international economic circumstances is too important and delicate a task to seriously contemplate these measures from another age.

The Opposition continues to promote-despite international trends to the contrary-the value of massive public sector job creation schemes. The fundamental point is that these schemes do not and cannot provide sustainable employment in the long term except at massive cost. Indeed their very introduction on a massive scale prevents the establishment and maintenance of conditions designed to generate substantial employment opportunities. Further, the Opposition's wages, industrial relations and other manpower-related policies are designed to fossilise the labour market and accentuate the basic problems. In particular, they fail to recognise that a sense of realism and flexibility needs to be imposed into the labour market, and economic thinking generally in Australia is to take advantage of the opportunities in the future. The behaviour of the Australian trade unions contrasts sharply with that recently displayed by a number of American trade unions where the difficult economic conditions have injected a sense of realism into their wage claims. In conclusion, there is no disagreement that Australia, in keeping with most Western industrialised countries, is experiencing historically high unemployment levels. We are fully aware of the possible economic and social consequences and the range of manpower programs is directed at these. The important issue is that governments maintain meaningful and relevant policies. The recent OECD conference has reaffirmed the correctness of the approach of the present Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) delivered another message of gloom to Australia. His statement was at least an admission of failure, if not an abject surrender. On 11 March the Australian Bureau of Statistics released unemployment figures showing 482,600 people out of work in February. This meant that the figure had risen by 43,000 from January. The national unemployment rate has now reached 7 per cent, a rise from 6.3 per cent in February 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) tonight dealt in detail with the specific figures. I propose to deal with the attitudes of this Government to unemployment. But before doing that there are a couple of matters which I want to mention in relation to the speech of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore). Following the example of his Prime Minister, the Acting Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr Moore) when commenting on the figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, attempted to transfer the blame for unemployment to wage claims and industrial disputes. He has repeated that attempt again tonight. That is something which the people of this country will not tolerate any longer. This Government is here to govern. It is time that it stopped trying to transfer responsibility elsewhere. It must accept responsibility for almost half a million Australians out of work because of the failed economic policies of the Fraser Government.

The Minister also referred to the Opposition's policy. Clearly he does not understand the Opposition's policy or was attempting to distort it. It is not simply a question of job creation. It is an overall economic planning proposal, including manpower policies, which will remove the obscene situation in this country where we have shortages in skills and yet an outrageously high rate of youth unemployment. It is the overall economic program that the honourable member for Wills was referring to and not simply job creation. If the Minister does not understand that, it is a tragic reflection on his mentality. He also indicated this evening that there is no reason to panic with these figures. Having regard to the fact that unemployment in this country, taking into account hidden unemployment, is probably now at about 13 per cent, I wonder when the Minister will panic? At what stage is this Government going to panic?

TALK.START.PARA: —When it gets thrown out.

—Right. Instead of positive action this Government attempts to make the problem of unemployment less significant. It is a matter which does not concern this Government. A classic example of this tactic was the decision of the infamous razor gang to stop the collection and publication of Commonwealth Employment Service statistics on unemployment which on a regional basis provided the number of registered unemployed and the number of jobs available. Even those figures did not give the true statistics on unemployment. The honourable member for Wills referred to the 400,000 hidden unemployed but the CES figures were nevertheless too revealing for this Government, so it decided to change to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures based on a survey and subject to sampling and questioning errors and not related to regions as were the CES figures.

SPEECH.PARA: An analysis of the CES figures on a regional basis clearly shows why this Government decided to discontinue the collection of such figures. The figures released by the CES in Dandenong between 1975 and 1980 are an example of why this information is no longer available. Other regional figures in Victoria give the same sad reflection of the failure of this Government. The Dandenong CES figures in August 1975 showed 2,400 people registered as unemployed. By 1980, after almost five years of Fraser Government, that figure had increased to 4,075 . That is a staggering increase of 70 per cent in the number of registered unemployed in five years and that does not take account of the hidden unemployment referred to earlier. During each week of this Government the number of unemployed in that region went up by 6.5 persons weekly. No wonder the CES figures have been discontinued. During the same period, August 1975 to August 1980, the young unemployed in the area really felt the full force of the inhumane policies of the Fraser Government. The number of young registered unemployed more than doubled-from 826 to 1,749. Since August 1980 the unemployment position in this region has continued to deteriorate, and that is why these figures are no longer available. The present Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N.A. Brown) refuses to face this issue. When confronted on this matter he accused me of distortion. I repeat tonight the challenge to the Minister to allow the CES at Dandenong to collect and publish figures as at August 1981 on the same basis as it was done up to August 1980. This will give the answer as to why the regional figures are no longer available. The answer is that because this Government prefers to hide local unemployment figures. If that challenge is taken up the question of who is distorting the figures will be patently obvious.

The previous Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner), left a legacy of massive unemployment as a grotesque monument to his and the Government's incompetence and callous attitude to the unemployed. He refused to admit that job creation programs were necessary .

TALK.START.PARA: —So did this bloke.

—As the honourable member for Burke has said, a similar view was taken by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, but clearly he did not understand the problem. I think the previous Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs was probably far more insidious. In fact, at the request of a municipality I made representations to that Minister for the introduction of a specific and effective job creation program.
—That is an exercise in futility.

—Exactly. As the honourable member for Swan has indicated, it was an exercise in futility. The Minister replied in the obsessive rhetoric that is the hallmark of this Government, that is, the need for expenditure restraint rather than action on unemployment. This absurd attitude has been continued by the present Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. There are not enough jobs available yet both Ministers have refused to introduce any policy which has an element of job creation. The attitude of the present Minister was clearly demonstrated in his Press release of 30 August last year when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: At a time when the economy is growing and with it employment opportunities for the young, the Government considers the most practical way of helping young people is to provide increased education, training and work experience opportunities. In that way they will be able to improve their skills and better compete in the growing labour market.

Even if it is conceded that the Minister has the ultimate capacity for self- delusion, surely he does not believe that humbug. Does he really believe that young people suffering from depression, loneliness and frustration as a result of long term unemployment will suddenly be integrated into imaginery jobs? The jobs are not there.

TALK.START.PARA: —He would say anything.

—That is quite right. There are not enough jobs available and there is no job creation element in any policy of this Government. In fact, it still persists with its dogmatic opposition to job creation. This Government is incapable of governing this country. Already the Prime Minister has attempted to distance himself from the Victorian election. Why? It is because he knows the electors in that State will reach the same decision as did the people in Lowe. One of the major issues in both elections was and will be the total failure of this Government on unemployment. On this issue the Fraser Government has reached the depths of political depravity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Mr H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —To establish the veracity of the matter of public importance proposed by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and supported by the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy) on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, that is, the further sharp deterioration in unemployment in Australia and the responsibility of the Federal Government for this situation, both spokesmen have to establish two aspects. Firstly, they have to establish that recently there has been a significant worsening in the unemployment situation and, secondly, they have to sheet home the blame for that situation-even if they do establish it-to the present Federal Government. The honourable member for Wills cited statistics that certainly do indicate some recent deterioration, and I will deal with that in a moment, but he produced not one scintilla of evidence to sheet home the responsibility for that deterioration to the Government. Meanwhile the honourable member for Holt offered as the answer to the current problems the Labor Party's proposals for economic planning-the failed panacea of the Labor Party of more and more government intervention. The unshakable faith that Labor members have in the inherent wisdom of government is amazing when all the evidence is to the contrary-that in fact the most efficient and equitable economic system is that which is subject to market forces and not central direction.

SPEECH.PARA: No one denies that there has been some deterioration in the unemployment figures on the basis of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for February 1982. But on the basis of recent experience it is stretching the vocabulary to describe the situation as a sharp deterioration. The 7 per cent unemployment indicated by the February survey of the ABS is a disappointing increase in the light of the success which has been achieved by the Government over the last three years in reducing unemployment. But that February figure must be viewed in the light of the traditional higher levels of unemployment at that time of the year because of the influx of school leavers into the labour market and also the close down of industry over the Christmas-January period. As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Play a straight bat; keep the elbow up.

—I play a straighter bat than the honourable member for Wills, as I will show. Also, as the Minister said, one month's figures must not be taken in isolation because they do not give a true picture. Those figures need to be considered in the context of the favourable employment growth over the last three years. Over that period the annual increase in employment has ranged from 120,000 to 180,000 per annum. The figures must also be viewed in the context of the current international labour market performance, and on this basis Australia compares very favourably. As a major trading nation, Australia cannot isolate itself completely from the international economic environment. This has been acknowledged by the honourable member for Wills. The important thing is that the policies of the Australian Government minimise the detrimental impact of the international environment and the current international economic recession. This is where the performance of the Fraser Government is in marked and favourable contrast to that of the previous Whitlam Labor Government. Whereas the Whitlam Labor Government inherited an Australian economy which, as is demonstrated by a range of economic indicators applying at that time, was far healthier than those of the other industrialised countries, when the international recession hit it implemented policies which dramatically worsened that situation. Very quickly those same indicators showed that the Australian economy was performing far worse than those in the other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Worst among those policies, it allowed-indeed, encouraged-the rapid increase in wages with minimum award adult male wages increasing by 36 per cent and average weekly earnings by 28 per cent as against price increases of 16 per cent for 1974. This pronounced real increase in labour costs was entirely inappropriate in the changed international economic environment of the mid-1970s. It was first and foremost this domestic situation which caused unemployment to soar with employment in the private sector falling by over 150,000 in that 1974 period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about 1982?

—I will come to that in a moment. One must place these factors in their historical context. When it came to office in 1975, the Fraser Government initiated policies to redress the imbalances that had been created by Labor's policies, especially on the wages front. Its inflation first strategy of public spending restraint, wages restraint and limiting money supply growth slowly but surely achieved a favourable turnround in the economy, demonstrated by a range of economic indicators which since 1979 have included the labour market. I demonstrated that a moment ago by showing that in the three years since 1979 the increase in employment has ranged on an annual basis from somewhere between 120, 000 and 180,000.

SPEECH.PARA: This marked turnround in unemployment means that in each of those years the increase was something more than for the five previous years combined. But despite this significant improvement, unemployment remains unacceptably high. This is especially the case in the context of reduced but nevertheless continuing high inflation. Of course, this fact is borne out by the February figures that have been quoted. This situation is not the responsibility of the Federal Government as the honourable member for Wills and the honourable member for Holt would have us believe. Certainly, they produced no evidence to sheet home the blame for that situation to the Government. The reason for continuing high unemployment is that community expectations, combined with industrial, economic and political power, have allowed the present Government to treat only the symptoms and not the cause of the problem. The Fraser Government has been very effective in treating those symptoms to the envy of the industrialised world and thereby has achieved a significant improvement evident in our economy. But, unless it can treat the cause, our economy will not be restored to optimum performance. That basic cause is the absence in Australia of a free market in a range of economic activities, but most notably in the price of labour.

Almost everybody in our community, from low income earners to high income earners, from unskilled workers to the most skilled professions, has virtually been able to set a price for his labour which he chooses. For any commodity in a market economy, including labour, there is a price at which it will all be sold- that is, clear the market. Whether through the industrial muscle of a trade union or a professional organisation, or whether by influencing the political process to regulate markets to maintain artificial price levels, especially by excluding foreign competition, in Australia over a long period the price for labour has been set at a price higher than the market clearing price. If a shopkeeper consistently sets a price for an article above the market clearing price, some will be left on the shelf. Similarly, if the price of labour is consistently above the market clearing price, some will be left on the shelf; that is, unemployment will result. The more the price is above the market clearing price, the higher will be the level of unemployment. We were reminded of this only a few moments ago by the Minister when he quoted the former Labor Treasurer, the Honourable Frank Crean, who said that one man's pay rise costs another man his job. I understand from the remarks of the honourable member for Wills that to some degree he also agrees with that concept. That provides the basis for a bipartisan approach to the problem of employment which the honourable member for Wills has been advocating in recent times.

It is especially the case that wage increases greater than productivity increases must destroy jobs. The February figures, which indicate some increase in unemployment, have been directly influenced by this factor because recently there have been large wage increases, reduced working hours and also cost increases as a result of industrial disruption. Clearly, if jobs are to be provided for the unemployed, wages and salaries must fall to the market clearing level. I believe this requires a marked change in the attitude of the whole Australian community which, in its selfishness, has become geared to expecting more and more. In particular, this changed attitude must permeate the trade union movement if there is to be any hope of success. When the honourable member for Wills was formerly the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he often made a great song and dance about unemployment, as he has done in this debate tonight. But all such concern evaporated when the ACTU argued its case for higher and higher wages before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. To argue in this way is to raise the expectations of the Australian wage earner beyond what is an economic reality.

As I say, if we are to tackle this problem of unemployment, whether this Government is to be effective in solving it or whether we are to achieve it on a bipartisan basis, it is only on the basis of a changed attitude in the community that improvement will be achieved.
