PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the amount of income permitted to pensioners before the loss of 50c in each dollar of pension for each extra dollar of income has not changed since 1972 although the C.P.I. has risen by 161 per cent in that time;
That the amount of income permitted to pensioners before fringe benefits are disallowed has not altered since 1979 although the C.P.I. has risen by 20 per cent in that time; and
That pensioners are people who, while employed, paid taxes and contributed to compulsory superannuation schemes.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should increase both the amount of income permitted to pensioners before disallowance of fringe benefits and the amount allowed before the amount of pension received is reduced, to a realistic level; and also link those cut-off points to the C.P.I.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament as assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who respectfully showeth their anger and condemnation at the unrealistic low priority given to children's vacation programmes and other children's services which has resulted in the withdrawal of funds from programmes which provide an essential community service.
We protest at the disastrous effects this will have on parents and children.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government provide public funding for all children's services including vacation programmes to ensure quality services are available for all children and parents who require it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over plant variety rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
1. PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interest not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
1. Refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
2. Calls for a public enquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-79 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The proposals announced by the Minister Senator F. Chaney to amend the Social Services Act limiting the sum of money to be retained in a current cheque account to $2000 for a single pensioner and $3000 for a married couple are unacceptable in that:

both single and married pensioners are, at regular intervals, faced with meeting recurrent expenses in connection with home maintenance, insurance, motor vehicle repairs and so on, for which no financial provision or assistance is given;
that such recurrent expenditure, when coupled with unexpected or unplanned expenses arising from family crises, health or funeral costs, may quickly exceed the proposed new limits;
no other repository, except a current cheque account, is able to provide funds as conveniently, or at short notice to pensioners.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to consult with the Australian Pensioners League and other pensioner groups in order to arrive at just and equitable legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:

That the mining of uranium in Australia, the proposed development of a uranium enrichment industry in Australia, together with the possibilities of resumed atomic weapons testing in the Pacific and dumping of radioactive waste in this region, constitute a serious threat to the health and wellbeing of all Australian and Pacific people for many generations to come.
Your Petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
1. Stop the mining and export of Australian uranium, except for medical and research purposes.
2. Actively oppose the development of uranium enrichment and nuclear power plants, the testing of nuclear weapons, and the disposal of radioactive waste in the Australian and Pacific region.
3. Significantly increase research into alternative energy sources.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That family radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representations.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfillment of the aims of family radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That family radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind or service and support that family radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will support family radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government and Telecom Management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the telegram service in time of emergency; that the Government and Telecom management have undermined the Telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130% in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communiction has fallen by approximately 60% in that time .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and Telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard and cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament Assembled. This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian postsecondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling-such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. the government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That any proposal by the Government to threaten pensioners' entitlements to fringe benefits by establishing a ceiling on the allowable amount of savings in non-interest bearing accounts is completely unfair and does not take into account the natural need of all pensioners to maintain some savings for occasional expenses such as house maintenance.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with any such proposal, and should instead direct its attention to those pensioners who enjoy extremely high levels of extra income yet manage to remain within pension eligibility guidelines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the budget announcements which include the raising of, or imposing of, Sales Tax on the many items which must be provided by parents for their childrens' schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect Australia's students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading purposes, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential educational items.
Your petitioners request that the Government (or Senate) will not impose any further tax on these items which are needed for the educational progress of Australia's students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Budget imposition of additional sales tax to both existing sales taxed items and to previously exempt goods:
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing; textiles and footwear; boat-building;

(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12 of this year that there would be no increases in indirect taxation (without at the same time giving personal tax relief).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhumane manner.
That the population of harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from harp seal, Pagophilus groenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
the Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15 per cent disadvantage over other States during the past ten years in road funding,
and the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned school children attending Trinity college and St Joseph's Tobruk, Beenleigh, and Eagleby South State Primary School, Queensland, respectfully showeth:
That the annual slaughter of baby harp seals in Canada is an inhumane and bloodthirsty activity and is condemned by children as well as adults in the community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: that the Australian Government appeal in the strongest terms to the Canadian Government to stop the slaughter of baby seals in Canada.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We, therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions of Italian Immigrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth: That the Australian Government take urgent steps to formulate and approve a Social Security Agreement with the Italian Government based on the rights and the needs of Italian immigrant workers in Australia.

Moreover, with the present petition we request that the following important questions related to the pensions of Italian immigrants be urgently resolved within such an agreement; in particular we request:

1. That Italian immigrants who have gained the right to Australian pensions and are no longer resident in Australia to be given the opportunity to apply for and obtain the pension without having to return to Australia.
2. That periods of residence in Australia of less than ten years presently required by the Australian legislation be considered for some entitlement to the Australian pension.
3. That the issue concerning the unfair reduction applied to the pension of Australian residents who are receiving an Italian pension be resolved.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth: That your petitioners are aware that the proposed sales tax is only one aspect of a Budget needed to support the growth and development of our country.
And that every Australian, whether rich or poor must aid this aim.
But that the social conscience of a country must be judged by the way in which it responds to the needs of its poorest, most helpless citizens.
And that this latest imposition will be responsible for Australia being judged not only by its own people but by the rest of the world.

We, the citizens of Queensland most humbly pray that: In the cause of justice and equity, your Honourable Members will reject any attempt to impose a sales tax on all essential goods including packaging of foods, shoes, clothing, literature and building materials.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the serious youth unemployment problem is a direct result of the community 's failure to create sufficient jobs.

In these circumstances the decision to abolish Community Youth Support Schemes is a social retrogressive step. The CYSS Projects provide valuable support services and work training for many young unemployed.

We the undersigned believe that CYSS, and the community based support it stimulates, caters for a much broader range of needs than can possibly be matched by the proposed training schemes. The majority of young people currently participating in CYSS groups will be left high and dry, resulting in frustration and possible violence.

Your humble petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government reverse its decision to abolish CYSS projects and provide sufficient funds to enable the various CYSS centres to continue their valuable work with the young unemployed in the future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 June 1981, on the following papers presented by Mr Sinclair:
Report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and Consultants' Reports.
and on motion by Mr Killen:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is a most important one. Although the hour is late it is vital that we discuss the report as soon as possible. I will commence the discussion this evening by referring to a very specific aspect of the findings of the Dix Committee-those relating to management structure vis-a- vis what could be called the necessity to examine the industrial relations problems that have bedevilled the Australian Broadcasting Commission for some time. The Dix Committee proposes a management structure which involves the Parliament, the Minister for Communications, a board of directors and a national broadcasting consultative council. The great weakness with this issue-I speak from my earlier experience as Postmaster-General-is the problem of getting into people's minds the necessity for flexibility and creativity when dealing with commissions such as the ABC, the Australian Telecommunications Commission or the Australian Postal Commission. It is very clear that the rigidity of the Public Service Board has prevented some commissions from attracting the best personnel. Certainly, it has prevented the personnel from remaining and caused a lot of industrial strife. It is important, if there is to be an effective management structure in this area, that representatives of the staff be on the board of directors. That is essential. We did it-I think effectively-with both Telecom and the Postal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address honourable members quickly on a couple of specific matters. In this very creative, skilful area-unique in the types of personnel needed-we must have people with technical training. The personnel concerned fall within what could be called the engineering group and the operating group. Unfortunately over a considerable number of years there has been virtually a demarcation dispute within the structure of the ABC as to who was entitled to what rate of pay, according to whether one was an engineer or an operator. At one stage during their respective careers, the slaries of an engineer and an operator would be virtually on a par, or perhaps the engineering group would be getting more than the operators. It is recognised that the engineering group completes approximately six years training and the operating group about three years, so this very essential section of the whole technical structure of the ABC has been in some sort of turmoil in terms of equality of remuneration.

The Public Service Board has not helped one bit throughout that period. The difficulty is quickly identified. It is that the Public Service Board structure- married to what is now called the Department of Industrial Relations-is still looking at the personnel of the ABC as though they belonged to the Public Service. For example, it must astound honourable members to find that the creative people who design costumes for productions of the ABC are virtually equated with those who work in the Australian Government Clothing Factory. That is the Public Service Board approach to the issue. Honourable members can readily understand what sort of disaster it causes to tell creative people such as I have described: 'As far as we are concerned, you must be equated with something that we have now. In your case it would be the Government Clothing Factory.'

A similar attitude obtains in the other area to which I have referred, that of the engineers and operators. There has been a running contest to try to get wage justice, but it has not been forthcoming. I want to refer to a recent case to show what the arbiter thought represented justice. It dealt with this very matter-an application by engineers and lecturers for wage justice, and the determination was made as recently as last October. It was an attempt to restore engineers to a level that would be at least one of parity with the operators and commensurate with their position of many years ago. The ABC was not able to give the Commissioner a clear indication of its views. It has never had independent views because it has always had to do what the Public Service Board has directed . Thus the Commission has not the flexibilty or ability to give its employees wage justice. The Commissioner said:
Having carefully considered all of the implications . . . I have decided thta it is in the best interests of the . . . group-
He refers to the particular group concerned-
and of the ABC and its staff generally for the nexus which has existed with the APS to be now broken.

I would have thought that was pretty clear. If honourable members look at the nature of this decision they will find that it was designed to give employees justice dating from a period in 1980. It was made in percentage terms, and with a further percentage increase to pick up other factors that had applied since indexation, vis-a-vis Telecom and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. In other words, the analysis by the arbiter indicated clearly that, because of the evidence submitted to him and because of what had happened in other areas, these people were given an increase in salary. Having been alerted to the fact that further increases are being sought, particularly by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and the possibility of a general $25 increment being granted-and of an increase being granted to metal trades employees-I am worried that within a matter of weeks there will be further movement in the Public Service structure ; in other words, that offers will be made to people within that structure on that basis. The operators, who are the ones who have been what could be termed running in tandem with the engineers, are likely to get that increase because that is the way they have always operated. The ABC-anxious to guarantee that it could at least remain on air, because technically, without the assistance of the engineering staff, programs could neither be produced nor put on air-sought, in desperation, a little guidance from the Department of Industrial Relations. It wanted to know whether it could give the engineering group the remuneration that would be given to the other group. An incredible answer received from the Department, as recently as a few days ago, clearly indicated that as far as it was concerned the engineers would get no further increase. The engineers might well decide not to continue working. Over a number of years there have been all sorts of difficulties in the ABC, for the very valid reason that these people have not received justice. Consider some of the problems that the Commission has had in trying to remain viable with a depleted technical and professional staff. The number of engineers has dropped from 700 to 400. It was suggested that 728 were needed, but the Commission now has 420, a shortfall of 308. Is it any wonder that the equipment is not up to standard, that there are faults in production, and all these things are happening solely because it is the Government's economic strategy to say that it cannot afford to extend to such people salary justice. It is essential, when we consider the submissions made to the Dix Committee and the decision by the arbiter concerning the breaking of the nexus, that the Commission be able to determine its own wages and conditions, as does the British Broadcasting Corporation.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: The Parliament: Personal Attacks on Members-Armed Services: Chaplain's Pay Rates -Immigration-Aborigines-Aboriginal Land Rights-Passports: Department of Foreign Affairs-Electorate of Dawson

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Parliament: Personal Attacks on Members-Armed Services: Chaplain's Pay Rates -Immigration-Aborigines-Aboriginal Land Rights-Passports: Department of Foreign Affairs-Electorate of Dawson

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to read to the House what was said on the adjournment debate on 29 November 1962, at page 2820, when the then member for Ballarat, Mr Dudley Erwin, made a personal attack on three members of the Opposition at that time. Dudley Erwin was a backbench member of the Government. He later became a party whip and still further on was appointed to the Ministry of one of the conservative governments of this country. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I ask why certain members of the staff of the Russian Embassy, particularly one Mr Ivan Skripov, a first secretary of the Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, has been a regular visitor to this House and has been cultivating the friendship of certain members of the Australian Labor Party , in particular the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren), the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Haylen) and the honourable member for Hunter (Mr James). Have these members been inspired by this Soviet diplomat to ask questions on a number sensitive foreign policy issues, and have they been briefed for foreign policy debates?

That was a smear or an allegation made under privilege against members. Within a few months, Skripov was persona non grata in this country and because of certain allegations arising out of this speech which were made in the newspapers of the day, I took libel action. In March 1964, when evidence came before the court, it was found that an article had been written by a John Bennetts of the Melbourne Age in July of 1962 giving all the detail's of Mr Erwin's speech several months before the speech to which I have referred was made in this Parliament. If people look at page 2820 of Hansard of 29 November 1962, they will find that Mr Erwin was reading under privilege his speech, which would have been written by Mr John Bennets. The fact is that on two occasions two honourable members drew to the Speaker's notice that at that time it was against Standing Orders to read one's speech on the adjournment debate.

This speech contained smears and allegations. The court case was so significant that it went through a jury of twelve, the Full Supreme Court of New South Wales , the full High Court then on to the Privy Council. It then came back to a second trial and then a further appeal to the Full Supreme Court. Two counts went on to the High Court and one count came back to a third trial. It was only then that Australian Consolidated Press surrendered and apologised to me. That smear was made by a Government member. It was not an isolated smear; I have heard other smears throughout my years in this Parliament.

Today, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) spoke on a subject. They were both here at the time when that allegation was made. Yet it seems to me that an endeavour is being made to develop double standards in this Parliament whereby because members are Ministers or Deputy Prime Ministers there is a standard for them and another for others. I mention also the allegations made against my colleagues Jim Cairns and Rex Connor. I could name other members who were smeared by Government members, but they did not get the defence that it seems to me the Deputy Prime Minister is seeking.

It disturbs me that today, when I sought to raise some of these issues, I was gagged by the Deputy Whip of the Government. He would not allow this evidence to come forward even although Government members had smeared other members in the past. I have referred only to my own experience. I have seen many members throughout the years smeared. Now the Government wants to put forwared a motion. I am disturbed about the first part of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is not free to raise a matter that has been the subject of discussion and resolution in the day's proceedings.
—I accept your ruling and therefore will end. I did want to raise the earlier part. I want to say clearly that no honourable member of this place should seek double standards.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the Australian community as a whole welcomes the recent pay rises granted to members of the armed Services. Certainly, as the member representing Victoria Barracks and Garden Island in Sydney, I do. The decision is an essential part of the new defence policies being developed by the Government. However, one serious anomaly stands out. I refer to the inexplicable neglect of a small but significant group, the 90 chaplains to the armed Services.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1981 pay rises announced by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) on 15 December last year meant that a private had his pay increased by $1,900 a year, a major by about $3,700 and a major-general by over $8,000. Service allowances paid to officers of the rank of major or below to allow for the special circumstances of service life have been increased from $1,652 a year to $2,500 a year. I certainly agree in general with what the Minister said last year. He said:

The Government has accepted that the existing salary structure in the Defence Force requires revision to eradicate anomalies and inequities which have existed for many years and to enable it to fulfil contemporary needs.

However, why is this small group of 90 chaplains to be excluded so that the starting salary of a chaplain-$17,469 a year-is now less than that of the highest grade corporal, at a starting out salary of $17,700 a year, and considerably less than that of a captain, the rank which is customarily seen as a chaplain's equivalent, at a starting out salary of some $22,739 a year. A chaplain of 18 years' seniority now receives $27,471 a year while a captain of five years' seniority receives $28,286. The only change is that a new rank of principal chaplain has been introduced, at a salary of $29,000 a year. What reason has been advanced for this neglect of chaplains? I turn to the report of the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay which was presented to the Minister for Defence on 4 November 1981. The committee said:
It seems clear that the conditions of service for chaplains in the Defence Force have surpassed by a considerable margin those conditions which apply generally to chaplains in the community at large.

Yet, according to my information, in terms of movement alone this is not the case. In the average Uniting Church parish a Minister can reckon on a stay in the one parish of five to 10 years. In the Presbyterian and Anglican Churches, the period of tenure is much longer than that. How can this compare with the frequent movements of service life? A chaplain will find that within a decade his children have attended more than 10 schools. The report recommends that an independent review be completed on chaplains' pay scales. I understand also that the Department of Defence is reconsidering the situation. Nevertheless, what concerns me is the lack of interest in any value on the work of chaplains in our armed forces that is revealed by this dilatory approach. Quite apart from the spiritual services provided to those who seek them, chaplains have invaluable roles to play in the provision of welfare to all ranks and in the maintenance of morale. Their duties extend from lecturing in colleges and apprenticeship training schools to marriage counselling. They share the roughest of conditions with the men and are generally on call 24 hours a day. Why are such services not given their due? Do we want them to be belittled and whittled away or do we want those who provide those services adequately recompensed? Do we want recruits of the highest calibre added to their numbers? As I have said, only about 90 chaplains serve over 60,000 personnel of the armed services. Surely we can afford to be more generous to this devoted group who for the first time have been excluded from the pay rises offered to all other personnel of the armed services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some remarks on the whole issue of immigration, following the debate on immigration that occurred today. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) in his remarks, especially in his reply to comments made in the debate, sought to throw cold water on certain humanitarian concerns of honourable members and talked a great deal about the onerous difficulties involved in maintaining a sensible immigration policy, especially in the area of refugees. No one denies that serious difficulties are involved when people have to be turned away or their applications have to be delayed. Everyone knows that over one million people are applying and only just over 100,000 are being admitted.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I was disturbed to hear the Minister imply that the economic difficulties we are witnessing at the present time should be the major consideration in setting limits on the level of immigration and refugee intake. I think that shows a severe deficiency in the Government's policy. There is no general population policy on which the Government bases an immigration policy. The Government simply proceeds by a series of ad hoc adjustments and measures, without determining a general policy on population growth and the role of immigration in that context. Last year in the review of demographic trends we were told that Australia had reached the stage of zero population growth; that is, without immigration there would be no natural increase in population, our numbers would remain stagnant and perhaps would even reduce. We were told also- this has been repeated many times by Ministers who have not wanted to grant increases in the pension or who have wanted to reduce the rights of pensioners- that the number of old people in Australia as a proportion of the total population is increasing dramatically; indeed, by the mid-1990s the number of Australians over 65 years of age will increase by 50 per cent and those of over 70 years of age will increase by 100 per cent.

Those facts show that there is a need for a coherent population policy. Unless we force people to have more babies, immigration is absolutely necessary to resolve that problem. The Minister should be emphasising that fact rather than conceding to those minority sectors of the community which seek to blame the economic problems on immigration. We have had enough debates about the causes of economic problems. I believe that no credence should be given to honourable members on either side of the House who try to blame immigration for our economic problems at the present time. What is required is more research and discussion towards developing a population policy which takes into account the various factors concerned and which places the role of immigration in its proper perspective. Most other nations have a population policy of that kind. We need to work towards developing such a population policy.

Finally, let me make a couple of remarks about the refugee policy. The Opposition accepts the importance of refugees as part of our total immigration intake, although I am not entirely sure that there should not be some separation between refugees on the one hand and what is probably called migration on the other hand, so that people who want to migrate to Australia are not affected by changes in the total number of refugees taken in. Perhaps in an overall population policy we ought to think about separating one group from the other. I do not have time to elaborate on this point tonight, but I will do so at another time. I still believe that the measures outlined in the Minister's statement allow him to assume a part of an unbalanced policy in terms of where the refugees will come from. We still do not have set down principles which state that the refugee policy should be balanced so that refugees from all sections of the world where they exist have an equal right to apply for entry to Australia and to come to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem when talking about Aboriginal culture and customs is that many white Australians have no understanding of the first settlers in this country, the Aboriginal people. I do not say they lack sympathy because if they had the opportunity to travel to the northern areas of Australia to meet and talk to Aboriginals in their own settlements, as I have done, they would appreciate the problems. I want to say a few words tonight in relation to a letter I have received from the Chairman of the Central Land Council of the Northern Territory, Mr Stan Scrutton. As he points out in his letter, the issue of sacred sites is of fundamental importance to Aboriginal people as it is an issue both of justice and of religious tolerance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government of the Northern Territory is attempting to promulgate legislation with the aim of watering down the definition of Aboriginal sacred sites in the Northern Territory. It is clear that the intention of this legislation is to make sure that the determination of whether a site is sacred or not will depend not on the criteria established by Aboriginal law and tradition but on criteria determined by the Northern Territory administration. It is also clear that the reason for the proposed legislation is to enable the developers and government instrumentalities to proceed with the construction of buildings, factories and mines, without the impediment of having to take into account the religious traditions of the Aboriginal people. I quote from the Central Land Council Press release on this matter:

It is difficult to convey the enormity of such activities to the European mind. It was like condoning the desecrating of a war cemetery to build a sewerage farm or the bulldozing of a cathedral to sink a mining shaft.

The proposed legislation was introduced without consultation with the Aboriginal people and, I understand, may also require an amendment to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act by the Commonwealth Parliament. One of my reasons for speaking tonight is to alert the House of Representatives to this grasping piece of proposed legislation with the aim of ensuring that any approach to amend the Commonwealth Act is rejected by this Parliament. It would seem that the Northern Territory Government has completely lost sight of the real nature of the Aboriginals and their attachment to the land, particularly their sacred sites. The sites are related to the Dreamtime, a period measured in thousands of yers, not in the mere 250 years of white European settlement. Only the Aboriginal people who have been taught Aboriginal laws and customs can identify the sacred sites. Songs and corroborees are associated with them and they are a vital part of tribal ceremonies. The land, animals, trees and plant life of the sacred sites are of great religious significance to the Aboriginal people. The changes proposed by the Northern Territory Government will result in the destruction of the sacred sites and this will ultimately lead to the destruction of the Aboriginal people as an independent race with a separate identity and a separate culture.

Finally, I would like to quote from an address given by one of our most distinguished Australians, Dr H. C. Coombs. Dr Coombs, when speaking on an Australian Broadcasting Commission Guest of Honour program, said:

In taking the land, we did not merely deprive Aborigines of property. We took also the source of their livelihood, the very foundation of their society, the basis of the rights and obligations on which it was built, and above all the source of the religious convictions which gave purpose and justification to their lives.

I call on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to recognise the attack by the Northern Territory Government on the rights of the Aboriginal people by resisting pressures from vested interests which seek to turn back the clock and introduce legislation that can only result in a renewal of spiritual degredation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just recently a report from the Mackay Regional Development Bureau came into my hands. I thought it would be interesting to quote some of the figures in the report which refer to my electorate of Dawson. The Bureau estimates that for the year ended June 1981 total exports from the Mackay region amounted to nearly $1 billion-the figure was $978.72m-and accounted for 5.12 per cent of total Australian exports. As Mackay represents about 75 per cent of the population of the entire electorate, I then took into account some of the export aspects that were not covered by the Mackay figures. For the year ended June 1981 the value of sugar was $556m, coal exports amounted to $710m, beef approximately $80m and tourism $40m. When I threw in about $10m for other activities I was left with the startling figure of $1.4 billion which represents 7.3 per cent of total Australian exports.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pay a tribute to the Bureau for bringing this information to my attention and to the attention of the people it serves. But more importantly the report gives me an opportunity to indicate to the House that there are wealthy electorates such as Dawson throughout Australia which contribute not only to our export trade but also generally to the revenue of governments, State and Federal . In fact, looking at the figures for the year ended June 1980, the electorate of Dawson contributed the greatest amount of personal taxation of any Federal electorate in Queensland. In addition, tax paid by mining giants such as Utah certainly made a major contritution to Commonwealth coffers. Wealth collected from this source will further increase. Within the last fortnight I did a rather extensive tour around the coalfields in the northern section of the Bowen Basin where Mt Isa Mines Ltd is developing a port facility at Abbot Point. An expansion program is being undertaken at Collinsville itself. The newest in the Newlands mining lease at Newlands will have an attached satellite town of Glenden catering for a couple of thousand people. This total development will cost in the vicinity of $550m. At the bottom of the electorate, further development is being carried out at Middlemount. In fact, this development trained its first coal from German Creek only a couple of week ago. That development will cost $400m. If we couple this development with the contemplated coke works to be sited near the Hay Point export harbour, we are talking about another $1 billion. The Condor shale oil deposits at Proserpine just north of Mackay are under investigation now to the tune of $23m to see whether the shale oil in that area might be developed. Added to that, the Comalco company is talking about smelters and refineries around Bowen.

I want to point out that private enterprise, using Australian capital and some overseas capital, is developing the division of Dawson and north Queensland. Very little contribution is being made to this expansion by the State or Federal governments. I realise that Federal revenue has to be spent in areas such as welfare, health and education. But these are non-productive areas in that they generate the same amount of expenditure each year. I believe it behoves Government, particularly the Commonwealth Government, to make sure that the wealthy electorates , those that are producing the wealth for Australia, are also given some assistance. I feel that if assistance in respect of roads were given to electorates such as Dawson and indeed all those electorates in north Queensland, productivity would improve, and wealth would increase, resulting in additional revenue to the Commonwealth. The biggest difficulty I have is justifying the expenditure of Commonwealth revenue from the point of view of what is required in return. Roads, both national highways and secondary highways , are certainly a major item. Also of importance are water research and water facilities. In fact, something along these lines is being done in respect of the Burdekin Dam. However, more needs to be done in this area. In addition, attention should be given to soil conservation research to go hand in hand with the development of the grain lands west of Mackay.
